revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1690|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1690'''.
==Events== *[[December 10]] – Playwright [[Henry Nevil Payne]] is tortured for his role in the [[Montgomery Plot]] to restore [[James II of England|James II]] to the throne — the last time a political prisoner is subjected to torture in Britain. *[[Colley Cibber]] becomes an actor with the [[Drury Lane]] company.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Nicholas Barbon]] – ''A Discourse of Trade'' *[[Pierre Bayle]] (attributed) – ''Avis important aux refugies'' *Sir [[Thomas Browne]] (posthumously) – ''[[A Letter to a Friend]]'' *[[Antoine Furetière]] (posthumously) – ''Dictionnaire universel'' *[[John Locke]] **''[[An Essay Concerning Human Understanding]]'' (dated this year but published 1689) **''[[Two Treatises of Government]] *[[Samuel Pepys]] – ''Memoires of the Navy'' *[[Baro Urbigerus]] – ''Aphorismi Urbigerani''
===Drama=== *John Bancroft – ''King Edward III, with the Fall of Mortimer, Earl of March'' *[[Aphra Behn]] (posthumously) – ''The Widow Ranter'' *[[Thomas Betterton]] – ''[[Dioclesian|The Prophetess, or The History of Dioclesian]]'' (adapted from [[John Fletcher (playwright)|Fletcher]] and [[Philip Massinger|Massinger]]'s ''[[The Prophetess]]'', with music by [[Henry Purcell]]) *[[Edmé Boursault]] – ''Esope à la ville'' *[[Roger Boyle, 1st Earl of Orrery]] – ''Mr. Anthony'' *[[John Crowne]] – ''The English Friar, or the Town Sparks'' *[[John Dryden]] **''[[Amphitryon (Dryden)|Amphitryon, or the Two Sosias]]'' **''Don Sebastian'' *[[George Powell (playwright)|George Powell]] **''Alphonso, King of Naples'' **''The Treacherous Brothers'' *[[Elkanah Settle]] – ''Distress'd Innocence, or The Princess of Persia'' *[[Thomas Shadwell]] – ''The Scourers'' *[[Thomas Southerne]] – ''Sir Anthony Love'' *"W. C." – ''The Rape Reveng'd, or the Spanish Revolution'' (adapted from [[William Rowley (dramatist)|William Rowley]]'s ''[[All's Lost by Lust]]'')
===Poetry=== *[[Thomas D'Urfey]]: **''Collin's Walk Through London and Westminster''<ref name=cocel>Cox, Michael, editor, ''The Concise Oxford Chronology of English Literature'', Oxford University Press, 2004, {{ISBN|0-19-860634-6}}</ref> **''New Poems'' *''See also [[1690 in poetry]]'' *[[Antonio Hurtado de Mendoza]] – ''Obras líricas y cómicas, divinas y humanas''
==Births== *[[February 3]] – [[Richard Rawlinson]], English antiquary and cleric (died [[1755 in literature|1755]]) *[[September 12]] – [[Peter Dens]], Netherlandish theologian (died [[1775 in literature|1775]]) *1689/90 – [[Susanna Highmore]], English poet (died [[1750 in literature|1750]])
==Deaths== *[[March 21]] – [[Henry Teonge]], English diarist and cleric (born [[1621 in literature|1621]]) *[[May 5]] – [[Theodore Haak]], German-born English translator and natural philosopher (born [[1605 in literature|1605]]) *[[May 12]] – [[John Rushworth]], English author of ''Historical Collections'' (born c. 1612) *[[October 3]] – [[Robert Barclay]], Scottish Quaker writer (born c. 1648) *[[October 25]] – [[Cornelius Hazart]], Dutch Jesuit controversialist (born [[1617 in literature|1617]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Franciscus Plante]], Dutch poet (born [[1613 in literature|1613]]) *''Probable year of death'' – [[Jeremias Felbinger]], German writer, teacher and lexicographer (born [[1616 in literature|1616]])
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1690 In Literature}} [[Category:1690 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:Peones.gif|frame|An example of a rendered [[animation]]]] '''Rendering''' in [[visual art]] and [[technical drawing]] means the process of formulating, adding [[color]], [[shading]], and [[texture (visual arts)|texturing]] of an image. It can also be used to describe the quality of execution of that process. When used as a means of expression, it is synonymous with [[illustrating]]. However, it may be used for mere [[Visualization (computer graphics)|visualization]] of existing [[data]] regardless of any preconceived message or idea to express. Rendering is also a technique that can be used while designing packaging and branding.
The alternative method to rendering an image is capturing an image such as [[photography]] or [[image scanning]]. Both rendered and captured images can be [[Mixed_media|mixed]], [[image editing|edited]], or both.
==Rendering style== '''Artistic rendering''' is the application of [[style (visual arts)|visual art style]]s to rendering. For [[photorealistic]] rendering styles, the emphasis is on accurate reproduction of light-and-shadow and the surface properties of the depicted objects, [[composition (visual arts)|composition]], or other more generic qualities. When the emphasis is on unique interpretive rendering styles, visual information is interpreted by the artist and displayed accordingly using the chosen [[art medium]] and level of [[abstraction]] in [[abstract art]]. In [[computer graphics]], interpretive rendering styles are known as [[non-photorealistic rendering]] styles, but may be used to simplify [[technical illustration]]s. Rendering styles that combine photorealism with non-photorealism are known as [[Hyperrealism (visual arts)|hyperrealistic]] rendering styles.
==See also== [[File:X-plane artistic render.jpg|thumb|X-plane artistic render]] * [[2D computer graphics]] * [[3D computer graphics]] * [[Graphic art software]] * [[List of artistic media]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Artistic Rendering}} [[Category:Artistic techniques| ]] [[Category:Technical drawing|Rendering]] [[Category:Infographics]]
{{Art-stub}}

{{for|the EP by The Orb and Meat Beat Manifesto|Battersea Shield (EP)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Use British English|date=February 2017}} {{infobox artefact |name = Battersea Shield |image =[[File:British Museum Battersea Shield.jpg|220px|alt=bronze shield]] |image_caption = On display in the British Museum |material = Bronze |size = Length: 77.7 cm
Width: 34.1–35.7 cm
Weight: 3.4 kg |writing = |created = [[British Iron Age|Iron Age]], c.350–50 BC |place = [[River Thames]], [[London]] |location = Room 50, [[British Museum]], London |id = |registration = {{British-Museum-db|1857,0715.1|id=831341}} }} The '''[[Battersea]] Shield''' is one of the most significant pieces of ancient [[Celtic art]] found in Britain. It is a sheet [[bronze]] covering of a (now vanished) wooden [[shield]] decorated in [[La Tène style]]. The shield is on display in the [[British Museum]], and a replica is housed in the [[Museum of London]]. ==History== The Battersea Shield is currently dated by the museum to c.350–50 BC, though later dates up to the early 1st century AD have previously been suggested. A date in the later part of this range is usually preferred; [[Miranda Aldhouse-Green]] is typical in using "2nd-1st century BC".Green, 104-105 It was dredged from the bed of the River [[Thames]] in [[London]] in 1857, during excavations for the predecessor of [[Chelsea Bridge]]; in the same area workers found large quantities of [[Roman military personal equipment|Roman]] and [[Celtic warfare|Celtic]] weapons and skeletons in the riverbed, leading many historians to conclude that the area was the site of [[Julius Caesar]]'s crossing of the Thames during the 54 BC [[Caesar's invasions of Britain|invasion of Britain]], although it is now thought that the shield was a votive offering, which probably predates the invasion. ==Description== [[File:London - British Museum - 2453.jpg|thumb|Battersea Shield closeup]] The Battersea Shield is made of several different pieces, held together by rivets concealed under the decorative elements. It is decorated with [[repoussé]] decoration, engraving, and [[vitreous enamel|enamel]]. The decoration is in the typically [[Celt]]ic [[La Tène]] style, consisting of circles and spirals. There are 27 small round compartments in raised bronze with red [[cloisonné]] enamel; the bronze within the compartment forms a sort of [[swastika]], thought to have been associated with good luck and also "solar energy".Green, 105 Enamel was a Celtic speciality, and reflects the use of red Mediterranean [[coral]] inlays in other British Celtic artefacts, such as the [[Witham Shield]], and here may perhaps be considered as an imitation of imported coral, though the use of enamel allows a more elaborate design. Some scholars have read a reversible human face into the decoration at the points where the smaller circles link to the larger one.Green, 104-105 The bronze sheet is said by archaeologists to be too thin to have offered effective protection in combat, and shows no signs of battle damage. It is therefore believed that the shield was cast into the river as a [[votive offering]], and made either as a "parade piece" or status symbol or specifically for votive offering. The metal plate of the shield that remains would have been fixed onto a plain, wooden or leather shield behind it. ==See also== *[[Witham Shield]] *[[Wandsworth Shield]] *[[Waterloo Helmet]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *[[Miranda Aldhouse-Green|Green, Miranda]] (aka Miranda Aldhouse-Green), ''Celtic Art, Reading the Messages'', 1996, The Everyman Art Library, {{ISBN|0297833650}} *Stead, Ian Mathieson (1985), ''The Battersea Shield'', [[British Museum Publications]], {{ISBN|0-7141-1375-1}}. ==External links== *[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_prb/t/the_battersea_shield.aspx British Museum: the Battersea shield] highlights page {{commons category}} {{British Museum}} {{authority control}} [[Category:Archaeological artefacts from the River Thames]] [[Category:Celtic art]] [[Category:Prehistoric objects in the British Museum]] [[Category:History of Surrey]] [[Category:Iron Age Britain]] [[Category:Bronzeware]] [[Category:History of the London Borough of Wandsworth]] [[Category:Votive offering]] [[Category:Individual shields]] [[Category:1857 archaeological discoveries]]

revision.text:
'''Bike Arc LLC''', located in downtown [[Palo Alto, California]], is a Silicon Valley startup that designs secure [[bicycle parking rack]]s and systems. It was founded by Joseph Bellomo and Jeff Selzer in 2008. Jeff Selzer sits on the Board of Directors of the Silicon Valley Bicycle Coalition<ref>http://bikesiliconvalley.org/board/</ref> and is the General Manager of Palo Alto Bicycles. Joseph Bellomo, a [[California]]-licensed [[architect]], is the founder and owner of [[Joseph Bellomo Architects]], Inc. in Palo Alto, which he founded in 1986. In addition to collaborating on Bike Arc, Mr. Bellomo and Mr. Selzer also worked together on the Palo Alto Bikestation at the [[Caltrain]] depot.
[[File:Rac Arc by Bike Arc in downtown Palo Alto, California.jpg|thumb|Rac Arc by Bike Arc in downtown Palo Alto, California]]
[[File:Half-Arc-by-Bike-Arc.jpg|thumb|Half Arc by Bike Arc in Lytton Plaza (downtown Palo Alto, Ca.). Bicycle parking/bike rack/bike storage.]]
[[File:Umbrella Arc by Bike Arc in downtown Palo Alto, California..jpg|thumb|Umbrella Arc bicycle parking system/bike racks/bicycle storage by Bike Arc.]]
In 2009, the American Institute of Architects, California Council, gave Bike Arc the Honor Award for Small Projects.<ref>{{cite web|title=2009 Honor Award for Small Projects|url=http://www.aiacc.org/2011/08/02/bike-arc/|publisher=AIACC}}</ref>
== Philosophy ==
Mr. Bellomo and Mr. Selzer—both being bicycle enthusiasts—set out to design bicycle-parking systems that don't touch and potentially damage bicycles, a solution that prevents bicycles from contacting each other, which can cause wear-and-tear.
== Products ==
Bike Arc is [[patented]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/patents/USD604207}}</ref> in both the United States and in Europe (Office for Harmonization In the Internal Market), and the company offers multiple iterations of the same fundamental concept: a [[modular]] [[structure]] of [[steel]] arcs. The Bike Arc family includes the Rack Arc, the Half Arc, the Umbrella Arc, the Tube Arc, the Car Arc, the Bus Arc, the House Arc, and the Ad Arc.
All Bike Arc products are manufactured in the United States.
== Installations ==
The City of Palo Alto has purchased and installed multiple Bike Arc products, including numerous Rack Arcs, Half Arcs and Umbrella Arcs, and Bike Arcs are also in public spaces in Boston, Las Vegas, Redwood City, California, and Norfolk, Virginia. They have also been installed at the University of Buffalo and the University of Nebraska, as well as—among others—at Juniper Networks, Inc., Varian Medical Systems, Inc., and the Seattle Repertory Theater.
== See also == *[[Bicycle locker]] *[[Bicycle parking]] *[[Bicycle]] *[[Cycling]] *[[Sustainable design]] *[[Sustainable architecture]] *[[Urban planning]] *[[City planning]]
== References == {{reflist}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090629055519/http://archpaper.com/e-board_rev.asp?News_ID=3608 ''Architect's Newspaper'', "Curve Your Wheels"] *[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/06/21/BUF217P3HV.DTL ''San Francisco Chronicle'', "Bicycle rack yields design for modular homes"] *[https://www.paloaltoonline.com/weekly/story.php?story_id=10844 ''Palo Alto Online'', "Business owners create bike racks that's state of the arc"] *[http://www.slashgear.com/bike-arcs-car-arc-solar-powered-car-port-keeps-your-electric-cars-and-bikes-charged-28104950/ ''SlashGear'', "Bike Arc’s Car Arc Solar Powered Car Port Keeps Your Electric Cars and Bikes Charged"] *[http://www.jetsongreen.com/2009/06/bike-arc-modular-bike-park-system.html ''Jetson Green'', "Bike Arc Modular Bike Park System"]
== External links == *[http://www.bikearc.com/ Bike Arc homepage] *[http://aia-awards.com/AIACC/gallery/projDisplay.php?RECORD_KEY%28ProjectInfo%29=id&id%28ProjectInfo%29=411&CatID=7 The American Institute of Architects California Council Design Awards, "Merit Award for Small Projects"]

{{EngvarB|date=March 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = Boss School of Music | logo = BossSchoolLogo1998.png | logo_size = 250px | caption = | fate = | foundation = 1996 | founder = | location_city = | location_country = India | area_served = [[Mumbai]], [[Thane]] | key_people = | industry = Music | services = Music education | homepage = }} The '''Boss School of Music''' was a [[Thane]]-based institution that conducted music classes in [[Mumbai]], India. The school conducted [[electronic keyboard]] music workshops in collaboration with the [[University of Mumbai]] from 1996 to 2005,<ref name="musnotes">{{cite news |title=Musical notes |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/17442707.cms|newspaper=The Times of India|date=29 July 2002}}</ref> until it came under controversy for allegations of [[witchcraft]] and [[black magic]], by parents of some students.<ref name="toiflee">{{cite news |title=Plot thickens: Music school owners flee|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2005-03-31/india/27850982_1_boss-school-music-school-parents|newspaper=The Times of India|date=31 March 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=He played exorcist every night|url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2005/apr/107661.htm|newspaper=Mid-Day|date=18 April 2005}}</ref> Cases were filed in the [[Bombay High Court]] regarding the same, and were later dismissed by the [[Supreme Court of India]].<ref name="outlooksc" /><ref name="middayblock" />
==Music education== [[File:Boss School Mazagaon Batch 1996.jpg|thumb|250px|Students learn music in a course conducted by the Boss School in Mazagoan, Mumbai (1998)]] [[File:Boss School Children Batch 2005.jpg|thumb|250px|School children learn music under the ''Music in Schools'' programme, conducted by the Boss School in Tardeo, Mumbai (2005)]] The Boss School of Music was founded as a nonprofit organisation in 1996.<ref name="examinerfun">{{cite news |title=Music Learning, A Fun Experience|newspaper=The EXAMINER Magazine|date=25 October 2003|author=Nancy D'souza}}</ref> The school conducted short-term [[electronic keyboard]] [[Music lesson|music courses]] in suburban [[Mumbai]] for novices and professionals,<ref name="hitkey">{{cite news |title=Hitting the right key|newspaper=Andheri West|date=25 July 2003}}</ref><ref name="coastmiracle">{{cite news |title=The Miracle of Music|newspaper=The Coastal Observer|date=July 1997}}</ref><ref name="secmaking">{{cite news |title=Music in the making – THE BOSS|newspaper=The Secular Citizen|date=July 1997|author=Wilson Pinto}}</ref> after which students could reportedly perform certain [[Musical composition|pieces]] on the electronic keyboard, [[Sight reading|read music notation]] and write their own [[Musical composition|compositions]].<ref name="musnotes" /><ref name="coastmiracle" /><ref name="secmaking" />
During its tenure, musicians, [[educationist]]s, doctors, artists and engineers joined the school as staff, working on a non-salaried basis to design better methods of music education.<ref name="ontrack2">{{cite news |title=Making Andheri Musical!|newspaper=Ontrack Suburbs|date=June 2003}}</ref><ref name="mmusical" /> They ran centres in [[Bandra]], [[Colaba]], [[Dadar]], [[Vile Parle]] and [[Churchgate]].<ref name="musnotes" /><ref name="hitkey" /><ref name="mmusical" /><ref name="ontrack3" /> They prepared students for standardised graded examinations conducted by [[Trinity College London]] in Mumbai, requiring 3–6 months of training using their methods.<ref name="examinerfun" /><ref name="ontrack2" /><ref name="ontrack3" /><ref name="ontrack1">{{cite news |title=Fun shortcut to that college seat|newspaper=Ontrack Suburbs|date=July 2003}}</ref> Such examinations reportedly required up to 8 years of training using traditional methods.<ref name="ontrack2" /><ref name="ontrack3" />
Their education method utilised [[Audiovisual education|audio-visual technology]] and simplified concepts.<ref name="mmusical">{{cite news |title=Mumbai made Musical|newspaper=The Asian Age|date=2 June 2003}}</ref><ref name="asianmaster" /> Students were provided with keyboards during classes,<ref name="examinerfun" /> and were given supplementary books and CDs printed and published by the school.<ref name="examinerfun" /><ref name="hitkey" /><ref name="coastmiracle"/><ref name="asianmaster" />
They entered into a collaboration with the Department of Music, [[University of Mumbai]] in 2002,<ref name="hitkey" /><ref name="asianmaster">{{cite news |title=Master Music|newspaper=The Asian Age|date=23 September 2002}}</ref> and conducted classes that could reportedly train a novice student into becoming a music teacher in 6 months.<ref name="musnotes" /> Dr. [[Vidyadhar Vyas]], Head of the Music Department at the university claimed that they "revolutionized" music learning by teaching complex musical concepts in short periods of time.<ref name="examinerfun" /><ref name="ontrack2" /><ref name="ontrack3">{{cite news |title=Musical Bonanza this Diwali|newspaper=Ontrack Suburbs|date=Oct 2003}}</ref>
==Controversy== In 2005, parents of some students filed cases in the [[Bombay High Court]] accusing the school of practising [[witchcraft]] and [[black magic]].<ref name="middayblock" /><ref name="dna" /> Investigations by the [[Mumbai Police]] found no evidence for such claims, and a local representative of [[Trinity College London]] confirmed that the examination certificates received by the students were authentic.<ref name="outlooksc" /><ref name="middayblock">{{cite news |title=Music school investigations hit roadblock|url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2005/apr/107182.htm|newspaper=Mid-Day|date=10 April 2005}}</ref> The police halted investigation awaiting evidence and witnesses for the allegations.<ref name="middayblock" /> Due to attacks by local mobs and fearing their safety, the school staff and researchers subsequently left their Thane premises.<ref name="toiflee" />
In 2008, several staff members of the school proceeded to the [[Supreme Court of India]] with cases against individuals, government officials and High Court judges for shutting down the institution, defamation and "[[witch-hunt]]ing", an act they termed "[[genocide]]".<ref name="outlooksc">{{cite news|title=SC orders inquiry into affairs of Boss School of Music|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=628740|newspaper=Outlook India|date=4 November 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325102521/http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=628740|archivedate=25 March 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="dna" /><ref>{{cite news |title=Controversial Boss School women members produced in SC|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/158922/content/219141/secret-my-longevity.html|newspaper=Deccan Herald|date=3 May 2011}}</ref> The Supreme Court dismissed their cases, reportedly because it contained allegations against high-ranking officials, judges and police.<ref>{{cite news|title=SC dismisses petition by Mumbai music school teachers|url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=574818|newspaper=Outlook India|date=26 May 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140325102437/http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=574818|archivedate=25 March 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The Supreme Court also arrested 4 of the staff members on grounds of contempt, after a staff member hurled a slipper at a Supreme Court judge.<ref>{{cite news |title=Woman hurls slipper at judge|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1090321/jsp/frontpage/story_10702272.jsp|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=21 March 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Contempt of court: 3-month jail for Boss School members|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/contempt-of-court-3month-jail-for-boss-school-members/531636/|newspaper=The Indian Express|date=22 October 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Boss Music School members face contempt music, SC sends 4 to jail|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-10-22/india/28088817_1_boss-school-justice-kabir-criminal-contempt|newspaper=The Times of India|date=22 October 2009}}</ref> The High Court cases regarding the allegations were dismissed by the Supreme Court.
Another three staff members filed cases in the [[Federal Court of Australia]], accusing the Sydney-based [[Exclusive Brethren]] sect for committing a "genocide" by destroying their group, and bribing Indian officials and judges to do so.<ref name="nzplea">{{cite news |title=Ex-Brethren in arrests plea|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/744543/Ex-Brethren-in-arrests-plea|newspaper=National NZ|date=3 December 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Exclusive Brethren an evil, corrupt cult, court told|url=http://www.culteducation.com/reference/exclusive_brethren/exclusive_brethren105.html|newspaper=Herald Sun|date=2 December 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Exclusive Brethren 'guilty of genocide, slavery'|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2008-12-02/exclusive-brethren-guilty-of-genocide-slavery/226320|newspaper=ABC Australia|date=2 December 2008}}</ref> Reportedly, they did not have the funding for proper legal representation, and appeared in court without lawyers.<ref name="nzplea" /> The Federal Court questioned its ability to order the [[Australian Federal Police]] to investigate the matter, and the case was adjourned.<ref name="nzplea" /> In 2009, a delegation of 12 Indian judges travelled to Sydney for an "exchange program" with the Australian Federal Court, which the Australian government offered to fund.<ref name="inexcji">{{cite news |title=In austere mode, govt in a bind over CJI's Australia trip|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/in-austere-mode-govt-in-a-bind-over-cjis-australia-trip/516728|newspaper=The Indian Express|date=14 September 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Oz junket for judges proves costly for Govt|url=http://www.topnews.in/oz-junket-judges-proves-costly-govt-2220459|newspaper=TopNews India|date=10 April 2009}}</ref>
While defending High Court cases that claimed she was "mentally unsound", one of the staff members received two gold medals from the [[Mumbai University]] for topping the board that year.<ref name="dna">{{cite news |title='Mentally unsound' girl tops Mumbai University|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/report-mentally-unsound-girl-tops-mumbai-university-1150684|date=2008-02-13|newspaper=[[DNA India]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Mentally unsound girl tops Mumbai University|url=http://indiaedunews.net/In-Focus/February_2008/%27Mentally_unsound%27_girl_tops_Mumbai_University_3422/|newspaper=India Edu News|date=2008-02-13}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Performing arts]] *[[Music education]] *[[Trinity College London]] *[[University of Mumbai]] *[[Supreme Court of India]] *[[Bombay High Court]] *[[Exclusive Brethren]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Music schools in India]] [[Category:Schools in Mumbai]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1996]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1996]] [[Category:1996 establishments in India]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=September 2010}} {{marketing}} '''Licensing''' means renting or leasing of an [[intangible asset]]. It is a process of creating and managing [[contracts]] between the owner of a [[brand]] and a company or individual who wants to use the brand in association with a product, for an agreed period of time, within an agreed territory. Licensing is used by brand owners to extend a [[trademark]] or character onto products of a completely different nature.<ref>{{citebook|title=Integrated Intellectual Asset Management|first= Steve|last= Manton|year=2005|publisher=Gower Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=0-566-08721-9}}</ref>
Examples of intangible assets include a song ("Somewhere Over The Rainbow"), a character ([[Donald Duck]]), a name ([[Michael Jordan]]), or a brand (The [[Ritz-Carlton]]). An arrangement to license a brand requires a licensing agreement. A licensing agreement authorizes a company which markets a product or service (a licensee) to lease or rent a brand from a brand owner who operates a licensing program (a licensor).<ref name="Brand Licensing Expert">[http://www.brandlicensingexpert.com BrandLicensingExpert.com Peter Canalichio, Licensing Brands, Inc. CEO]</ref>
== History == Brand licensing is a well-established business, both in the area of [[patent]]s and trademarks. Trademark licensing has a rich history in American business, largely beginning with the rise of mass entertainment such as the movies, comics and later television. [[Mickey Mouse]]'s popularity in the 1930s and 1940s resulted in an explosion of toys, books, and consumer products with the lovable rodent's likeness on them, none of which were manufactured by the Walt Disney Company.
This process accelerated as movies and later television became a staple of American business. The rise of brand licensing did not begin until much later, when corporations found that consumers would actually pay money for products with the logos of their favorite brands on them. [[McDonald's]] play food, [[Burger King]] T-shirts and even ghastly [[Good Humor]] Halloween costumes became commonplace. [[Brand extension]]s later made the brand licensing marketplace much more lucrative, as companies realized they could make real dollars renting out their equity to manufacturers. Instead of spending untold millions to create a new brand, companies were willing to pay a royalty on net sales of their products to ''rent'' the product of an established brand name. [[Armor All]] auto vacuums, [[Breyers]] yogurt, [[TGI Friday's]] frozen appetizers, and [[Lucite]] nail polish are only a handful of the products carrying well-known brand names which are made under license by companies unrelated to the companies who own the brand.
== Reasons for licensing == A company may choose to license its brand(s) when they believe there is strong consumer acceptance for [[brand extensions]] or products. For example, when [[Apple Inc.|Apple]] launched the iPod there was an immediate need for accessories such as headphones, charging and syncing stations and carrying cases. Apple decided not to manufacture these products and instead chose to have a [[licensee]] make the products. By doing so, Apple could offer branded "Earbud Headphones", "iPod docking stations" and "iPod socks." Each is made by a separate company but together offer the consumer an elegant solution. All of these accessories are sold by licensees.
Apart from benefits to licensors, there are benefits to licensees as well. Licensees lease the rights to a brand for incorporation into their [[merchandise]], but do not share ownership in it. Having access to major national and global brands, and the logos and trademarks associated with those brands, gives the licensee significant benefits. The most important of these is the marketing power the brand brings to the licensee’s products. When brand managers enter or extend into new product categories via licensing they create an opportunity for a licensee to grow their company. Below is an example of the licensed product process steps:
* Licensor chooses the product categories to be licensed * Licensor finds and negotiates a license with the best licensees * Licensees develop concepts, prototypes and final production samples and submit for approval * Licensor approves licensed products for sale * Licensees sell licensed products to authorized retailers<ref name="Marketing Professors">[http://www.marketingprofs.com/authors/971/pete-canalichio MarketingProfessors.com]</ref>
Licensees expect that the license will provide them with sales growth. This sales growth may be in the form of growth within existing market or the opportunity to enter a new market. To achieve this, licensees expect that the brand they are licensing has significant brand preference, that it will open doors and ultimately help them meet or exceed their business objectives. The licensing contract forces the licensee to achieve certain sales targets and royalties; therefore, the goal of the licensee is to quickly meet their business objectives, thereby achieving their contract obligations. [[Royalties]] are the monies paid to a licensor by the licensee for the right to use the licensed property. It is calculated by multiplying the Royalty Rate by the Net Sales.<ref name="Atlanta Business Radio">[http://atlantabusinessradio.businessradiox.com/atlanta-business-radio-interviews-swine-flu-expert-dr-elaina-george-brand-licensing-expert-pete-canalichio-and-batteries-plus-owner-john-cyphers/ Atlanta Business Radio Interview]</ref>
== Global brand licensing industry ==
The main international [[professional association]] for brand licensing is the [[Licensing Industry Merchandiser's Association]], which sponsors the annual Licensing International Expo.
The Society of Product Licensors Committed to Excellence (SPLiCE) is a Licensors Community of Practice with the vision to continuously improve brand licensing. The mission of SPLiCE is to act as a community of licensors who share best practices for protecting, promoting and enhancing brand integrity. The SPLiCE Licensors Workshop acts as its annual board of directors and members' meeting. During SPLiCE Licensors Workshop, benchmark findings and industry trends are highlighted in feature panel presentations that are relevant to the community at large. They engage a creativity philosophy of divergence and convergence to sustain unique idea implementation on best practices. The vision for SPLiCE Licensors Workshop is to provide best in practice licensing education through sharing educational best practices through benchmarking initiatives, task force collaborations, committee reports, and guest industry speakers
Each May, ''License! Global'' magazine publishes an annual list of "The Top 150 Global Licensors". For 2017, the leader was [[Disney Consumer Products]] with $53 billion in retail sales of licensed merchandise, followed by [[Meredith Corp.]] with $23.2 Billion and [[PVH (company)|PVH]] with $18 Billion.<ref>{{cite news|last=Anonymous|title=Top 150 Global Licensors|url=http://www.licensemag.com/license-global/top-150-global-licensors-3}}</ref>
According to the International Licensing Industry Merchandisers' Association (LIMA), global licensed merchandise sales was $272.2 billion in 2016, versus $262.2 billion in 2015. <ref>{{cite news |last=Stone |first=Michael |last2=Ames |first2=Allison |url=http://adage.com/article/agency-viewpoint/licensing-expo-2017-8-trends-263-billion-industry/309209/ |title=8 Trends Ahead for the $263 Billion Licensing Industry |work=[[Advertising Age]] |date=2017-06-01 |accessdate=2017-06-01 }}</ref>
== Brand licensing in India == {{unreferenced section|date=June 2013}} The liberalisation of the Indian economy in 1992 brought a slew of international brands to India. Many of these brands have been licensed to Indian companies. [[Arvind_(company)| Arvind]] represent Arrow, Cherokee, ELLE, Nautica, USPA, AEROPOSTALE, CHILDRENS PLACE, Ed Hardy, GAP and Kipling. The [[Murjani Group]] is the licensee for Calvin Klein Jeans, FCUK and Tommy Hilfiger. Beverly Hills Polo Club (BHPC) is licensed to Spencers Retail.
Character Licensing is another big licensing segment of brand licensing in India. The big players in the character licensing industry in India are [[Disney India]], [[Viacom 18]] and [[Cartoon Network Enterprises]]. Characters licensed out by Disney India include [[Mickey Mouse]] and [[Donald Duck]]. Viacom has brought in popular characters from [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]] like [[Dora The Explorer]] and [[SpongeBob SquarePants]]. Cartoon Network boasts of a portfolio including characters such as [[Ben 10]], [[Powerpuff Girls]], [[Mr. Bean]], [[Roll no. 21]], [[We Bare Bears]].
== Brand licensing in Italy == {{unreferenced section|date=October 2013}} Brand Licensing in [[Italy]] started in the seventies with very few Licensing Agencies. Apart from Disney which had its own dedicated office in the market, all the other big Entertainment majors were represented by independent agencies. One of these companies named DIC 2 (Distribution International Characters), founded in 1973 by Gianfranco Mari contributed to create the licensing business in Italy and set big phenomena as [[He-Man]] and the Masters of the Universe, [[Marvel Comics]], ''[[Star Wars]]'', [[Hanna & Barbera]] characters, [[Zorro]], [[Asterix]] and so on. DIC 2 is still one of the biggest independent agencies in Italy, representing different cartoon characters and famous brands.

[[Daniel Wuhrmann]] | director = [[Woody Allen]] | writer = Woody Allen | starring = {{Plain list | * [[Hayley Atwell]] * [[Colin Farrell]] * [[Sally Hawkins]] * [[Ewan McGregor]] * [[Tom Wilkinson (actor)|Tom Wilkinson]] }} | music = [[Philip Glass]] | cinematography = [[Vilmos Zsigmond]] | editing = [[Alisa Lepselter]] | studio = [[Wild Bunch (film company)|Wild Bunch]] | distributor = [[The Weinstein Company]] (USA)
[[StudioCanal UK|Optimum Releasing]] (UK) | released = {{Film date|2007|06|18|Avilés premiere|2007|10|31|France|2008|01|18|United States|2008|05|09|United Kingdom|df=y}} | runtime = 108 minutes | country = United States
France
United Kingdom | language = English | budget = $15 million | gross = $22,539,685 }} '''''Cassandra's Dream''''' is a 2007 [[drama film|dramatic]] [[thriller film]] written and directed by [[Woody Allen]]. Filmed in the United Kingdom, it was released in 2007 in [[Europe]] and in January 2008 in the United States. It was developed as a British-French-American co-production. The film was premiered in secret at [[Avilés]], [[Spain]] on June 18, 2007.{{cite news |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=spanish-town-beats-venice-to-woody-allen-premiere-2007-06-21 |work=Hurriyet Daily News (via Reuters) |date=June 21, 2007 |title=Spanish town beats Venice to Woody Allen premiere}} It was officially premiered at the [[Venice Film Festival]] on September 2, 2007 and was already in theaters in [[Spain]] by November 3.{{cite web |url=http://imdb.com/title/tt0795493/releaseinfo |title=''Cassandra's Dream'' (2007) – Release dates |work=IMDb}} The film had its [[North America]]n premiere at the [[Toronto International Film Festival]] on September 11, 2007.[http://www.tiff07.ca/industry/filmsandschedules/filmdetails.aspx?id=705151612311292 TIFF '07 – Films and Schedules ''Cassandra's Dream''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031011321/http://www.tiff07.ca/industry/filmsandschedules/filmdetails.aspx?id=705151612311292 |date=October 31, 2007 }} ==Plot== Brothers Terry ([[Colin Farrell]]) and Ian ([[Ewan McGregor]]), who live in [[South London]], were raised by a weak father Brian ([[John Benfield]]) who runs a restaurant, and a strong mother Dorothy ([[Clare Higgins]]) who taught her sons to look up to their uncle Howard ([[Tom Wilkinson]]), a successful plastic surgeon and businessman. The brothers buy a sailboat at an oddly low price, despite its near pristine condition. They name it ''Cassandra's Dream'', after a greyhound that won Terry the money to buy the boat. Knowing nothing of [[Greek mythology]], they are unaware of the ominous antecedents of this name—the ancient prophetess [[Cassandra]], whose prophecies of doom went unheeded by those around her. While driving home from a day's sailing in a borrowed car, Ian crosses paths with beautiful actress Angela Stark ([[Hayley Atwell]]), with whom he becomes infatuated. Terry has a [[gambling addiction]] that sinks him deeper in debt. Ian wishes to invest in hotels in [[California]] to finance a new life with Angela. To overcome their financial issues, they ask Howard for help. He agrees to help them, but asks for a favor in return: they must murder someone for him. Howard faces imprisonment for unspecified crimes and his future is threatened by Martin Burns ([[Phil Davis (actor)|Phil Davis]]), a former business partner who plans to testify against him. Howard asks his nephews to get rid of Burns, and in return he will reward them financially. After initial reluctance, the brothers agree. They make two [[Improvised firearm|zip guns]], untraceable and easily destroyed. Lying in wait in Burns' home, their plan is foiled when Burns arrives with a woman. Their resolve shaken, they leave and agree to commit the murder the next day. The next day, they succeed in carrying out the murder and later destroy the guns. Ian is content to move on as if nothing happened, but Terry is consumed by guilt and begins abusing alcohol and other drugs. His behavior frightens his fiancée ([[Sally Hawkins]]), who tells Ian about the situation and that Terry believes he has killed someone. After Terry confides that he wants to turn himself in to the police, Ian goes to Howard for advice. They agree there is no alternative but to get rid of Terry. Ian plans to poison Terry during an outing on the boat. Ian can't bring himself to kill his own brother, and attacks him in a fit of rage. In the chaos, Terry knocks Ian down the steps into the cabin, killing him. The boat is later discovered adrift by the police, and the audience learns that Terry snapped and drowned himself after killing his brother. The last shot is of ''Cassandra's Dream'', still in beautiful condition despite the tragedies it set in motion. ==Cast== * [[Colin Farrell]] – Terry Blaine * [[Ewan McGregor]] – Ian Blaine * [[John Benfield]] – Brian Blaine * [[Clare Higgins]] – Dorothy Blaine * [[Ashley Madekwe]] – Lucy * [[Andrew Howard]] – Jerry * [[Hayley Atwell]] – Angela Stark * [[Sally Hawkins]] – Kate * [[Tom Wilkinson]] – Howard Swann * [[Phil Davis (actor)|Phil Davis]] – Martin Burns * [[Dan Carter]] – Fred * [[Richard Lintern]] – Director * [[Jennifer Higham]] – Helen * [[Lee Whitlock]] – Mike * [[Hugh Rathbone]], [[Allan Ramsey (actor)|Allan Ramsey]], [[Paul Marc Davis]], Terry Budin-Jones, Franck Viano, Tommy Mack – Poker Players ==Soundtrack== {{Main|Cassandra's Dream (album)}} This is the first Woody Allen film since ''[[Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex* (*But Were Afraid to Ask) (film)|Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Sex* (*But Were Afraid to Ask)]]'' to have an original score commissioned for it. The score was composed by [[Philip Glass]]. It was also his first film released with a stereo soundtrack. Allen previously eschewed stereo although often employing [[Dolby Stereo]] and [[Dolby Digital]] technologies to convey a higher quality [[Monophonic sound|mono]] soundtrack.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} The film is stereo for its music only. {{Anchor|Reception}} ==Critical response== The film received mixed reviews from critics. Review aggregation website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a score 46% based on reviews from 116 critics.{{cite web|url= https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/cassandras_dream/|title=''Cassandra's Dream''|accessdate=January 21, 2008|publisher=Flixster|work=Rotten Tomatoes}} Another [[review aggregator|aggregator]] [[Metacritic]] gave the film an average rating score of 49 out of 100, based on 31 reviews.{{cite web|url= http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/cassandrasdream|title=''Cassandra's Dream'' (2007): Reviews|accessdate=January 21, 2008|publisher=CBS Interactive|work=Metacritic}} [[Manohla Dargis]] commended the film in her review for ''[[The New York Times]]''. Although offering criticism such as the film feeling "too lightly polished and often rushed, as if he had directed it with a stopwatch," she suggests that Allen's film "is good enough that you may wonder why he doesn't just stop making comedies once and for all."{{cite news|first=Manohla |last=Dargis|authorlink=Manohla Dargis|title=Movie Review - Cassandra's Dream (2007)|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2008/01/18/movies/18cass.html |date=January 18, 2008|work=The New York Times}} [[Roger Ebert]] compared the film negatively to [[Sidney Lumet]]'s similarly themed ''[[Before the Devil Knows You're Dead]],'' adding: "The Lumet film uses actors who don't look like brothers but feel like brothers. Allen's actors look like brothers but don't really feel related." He rated the film two out of four stars, and noted that Allen's previous film ''[[Match Point]]'' presented the material more effectively.{{cite news|first=Roger|last=Ebert |authorlink=Roger Ebert |title=Cassandra's Dream Movie Review (2008)|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/cassandras-dream-2008|date=January 17, 2008|work=The Chicago Sun-Times}} Damon Wise of [[Empire magazine|''Empire'' magazine]] concluded that ''Cassandra's Dream'' was "[a] clumsy, clichéd [[morality play]] that may actually represent the lowest point of Allen's recently chequered career." {{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/review.asp?DVDID=117905|title=Reviews:Cassandra's Dream}} [[Paul Jordan (artist)|Paul Jordan]] also compared the film to a [[morality play]]—but considered that praise: "Allen gets past the guard of a modern audience which would not have taken seriously the appearance of a [[Mephistopheles]] or an [[Old Scratch]]. Uncle Howard is a chilling 21st Century [[Tempter]], fulfilling the heart's desire in return for murder and leading his nephews to terrible [[Hell in Christian beliefs|perdition]]."Paul Jordan, "Persistent Myths," p. 17 In his "Best of the Decade" article, ''[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]'' critic Richard Brody called ''Cassandra's Dream'' one of the best films of the 2000s: "Few aging directors so cogently and relentlessly depict the grimly destructive machinery of life, and every time the word 'family' is uttered, the screws tighten just a little more."{{cite web |date=November 30, 2009|title=Best of the Decade|first=Richard|last=Brody|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/movies/2009/11/best-films-of-the-decade.html}} In 2016 film critics [[Robbie Collin]] and Tim Robey ranked it as one of the worst movies by Woody Allen.{{cite news|title=All 47 Woody Allen movies - ranked from worst to best|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/films/0/woody-allens-best-and-worst-movies/|accessdate=February 12, 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=October 12, 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0795493}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|id=cassandras_dream|title=Cassandra's Dream}} * {{metacritic film|id=cassandras-dream|title=Cassandra's Dream}} * {{mojo title|id=CassandrasDream|title=Cassandra's Dream}} * {{Amg movie|353472|Cassandra's Dream}} * [http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/read.php?ID=32045 DVD Talk discusses Woody Allen's dark side] {{Woody Allen}} {{Philip Glass}} [[Category:2007 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Films scored by Philip Glass]] [[Category:French thriller films]] [[Category:French films]] [[Category:American thriller films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British thriller films]] [[Category:2000s thriller films]] [[Category:2000s LGBT-related films]] [[Category:Neo-noir]] [[Category:Films directed by Woody Allen]] [[Category:Films set in London]] [[Category:Films set in Brighton]] [[Category:Screenplays by Woody Allen]] [[Category:Films produced by Letty Aronson]] [[Category:Films produced by Stephen Tenenbaum]] [[Category:Films produced by Gareth Wiley]] [[Category:Lesbian-related films]] [[Category:Bisexuality-related films]]

{{Infobox person | name = Chantal Akerman | image = Chantal Akerman - video still (cropped).jpg | imagesize = 225px | alt = | caption = Chantal Akerman in 2012 | birth_name = Chantal Anne Akerman | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1950|6|6}} | birth_place = [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2015|10|05|df=yes|1950|6|6}} | death_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] | death_cause = [[Suicide]] | nationality = Belgian | occupation = Film director, screenwriter, artist, and film professor | years_active = 1968{{ndash}}2015 | known_for = | notable_works = ''[[Jeanne Dielman, 23 quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles]]'' }} '''Chantal Anne Akerman''' ({{IPA-fr|akɛʁman|lang}}; 6 June 1950{{spaced ndash}}5 October 2015) was a Belgian [[film director]], [[screenwriter]], [[artist]], and [[Film studies|film professor]] at the [[City College of New York]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/07/arts/chantal-akerman-belgian-filmmaker-dies-65.html|title=Chantal Akerman, Whose Films Examined Women's Inner Lives, Dies at 65|website=The New York Times}}</ref> She is best known for her three hour [[magnum opus|''magnum opus'']] ''[[Jeanne Dielman, 23 quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles]]'' (1975), which was dubbed a "masterpiece" by ''[[The New York Times]]''. According to film scholar [[Gwendolyn Audrey Foster]], Akerman's influence on [[Feminism|feminist]] filmmaking and [[avant-garde]] cinema has been substantial.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Foster |editor1-first=Gwendolyn Audrey |editor1-link=Gwendolyn Audrey Foster |date=2003 |title=Identity and Memory: The Films of Chantal Akerman |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lULjtguX9HkC&pg=PA204 |publisher=SIU Press |page=204 |isbn=978-0809325139}}</ref>
==Early life and education== Akerman was born in [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]] to [[Holocaust]] survivors from [[Poland]].<ref name=nytobit /> She was the older sister of Sylviane Akerman, her only sibling. Her mother Natalia (Nelly) had survived years at [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]], where her own parents had died.<ref>{{cite web|title = Chantal Akerman obituary|url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/oct/08/chantal-akerman|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-10-10|first = Jonathan|last = Romney}}</ref> From a young age, Akerman and her mother were exceptionally close, and she encouraged her daughter to pursue a career rather than marry young.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://www.thejc.com/arts/film/chantal-akerman-my-family-and-other-dark-materials| title = Chantal Akerman: My family and other dark materials| website = www.thejc.com| access-date = 2016-02-27}}</ref>
At age 18, Akerman entered the [[INSAS (film school)|Institut National Supérieur des Arts du Spectacle et des Techniques de Diffusion]], a Belgian [[film school]]. Akerman dropped out during her first term to make the [[short film]] ''Saute ma ville''; she funded the film's costs by trading diamond shares on the [[Antwerp]] [[stock exchange]].<ref name=criterion>{{cite web |last1=Margulies |first1=Ivone |title=A Matter of Time: Jeanne Dielman, 23, quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles |url=http://www.criterion.com/current/posts/1215-a-matter-of-time-jeanne-dielman-23-quai-du-commerce-1080-bruxelles |website=The Criterion Collection |accessdate=18 August 2009}}</ref>
==Family==
Akerman had an extremely close relationship with her mother, captured in some of her films. In 1976 ''[[News From Home]]'', Akerman's mother's letters outlining mundane family activities serve as a soundtrack throughout the film.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Lebow|first1=Alisa|title=Identity Slips: The Autobiographical Register In The Work Of Chantal Akerman|journal=Film Quarterly|date=2016|volume=1|issue=70|pages=54–60}}</ref> The 2015 ''[[No Home Movie]]'' centers on mother-daughter relationships, largely situated in the kitchen, and is a response to her mother's death.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal|last1=Davies|first1=Jon|title=Every Home A Heartache: Chantal Akerman|journal=C: International Contemporary Art|date=2016|issue=130}}</ref> The film explores issues of [[metempsychosis]],<ref name="ReferenceB"/> the last shot of the film acting as a memento mori of the mother's apartment.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
Akerman acknowledged that her mother was at the center of her work and admitted to feeling directionless after her death.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> The maternal imagery can be found throughout all of Akerman's films, as an homage and an attempt to reconstitute the image and voice of the mother.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> In ''Family In Brussels'', Akerman narrates the story, interchanging her own voice with her mother's.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Work==
===Early work and influences=== Akerman claimed that, at the age of 15, after viewing [[Jean-Luc Godard]]'s ''[[Pierrot le fou]]'' (1965), she decided, that same night, to become a filmmaker. In 1971, Akerman's first short film, ''Saute ma ville'', premiered at the [[International Short Film Festival Oberhausen]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Margulies |first=Ivone |date=1996 |title=Nothing Happens: Chantal Akerman's hyperrealist everyday |location=Durham |publisher=Duke University Press |page=2 |isbn=0-8223-1723-0}}</ref> That year, she moved to [[New York City]], where she remained until 1972.
At [[Anthology Film Archives]] in New York, Akerman was impressed with the work of [[Stan Brakhage]], [[Jonas Mekas]], [[Michael Snow]], [[Yvonne Rainer]], and [[Andy Warhol]].
===Critical recognition=== Her first feature film, [[Hotel Monterey (film)|''Hotel Monterey'']] (1972), and subsequent short films, ''La Chambre 1'' and ''La Chambre 2'', reveal the influence of structural filmmaking through these films' usage of long takes. These protracted shots serve to oscillate images between abstraction and figuration. Akerman's films from this period also signify the start of her collaboration with [[cinematographer]] [[Babette Mangolte]].
In 1973, Akerman returned to Belgium and, in 1974, she received critical recognition for her feature ''[[Je Tu Il Elle|Je, Tu, Il, Elle]] (I, You, He, She)''. Feminist and queer film scholar [[B. Ruby Rich]] noted that ''Je Tu Il Elle'' can be seen as a "cinematic Rosetta Stone of [[Human female sexuality|female sexuality]]".
Akerman's most significant film, ''[[Jeanne Dielman, 23 Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles]]'', was released in 1975. Often considered one of the greatest examples of [[feminist]] filmmaking, the film makes a hypnotic, real-time study of a middle-aged widow's stifling routine of domestic chores and prostitution. Upon the film's release, ''[[The New York Times]]'' called ''Jeanne Dielman'' the "first masterpiece of the feminine in the history of the cinema". Chantal Akerman scholar Ivone Margulies says the picture is a filmic paradigm for uniting feminism and anti-illusionism.<ref name="criterion"/> The film was named the 19th greatest film of the 20th century by [[J. Hoberman]] of the ''[[Village Voice]]''.<ref>Hoberman, J. (2001) [4 January 2000]. "100 Best Films of the 20th Century: Village Voice Critics' Poll". The Village Voice (reprint ed.). Reprinted by AMC.</ref>
===Philosophy===
Akerman has acknowledged that her cinematic approach can be explained, in part, through the writings of [[Gilles Deleuze]] and [[Felix Guattari]].<ref name="Duke University Press">{{cite book|last1=Marguilles|first1=Ivonne|title=Nothing Happens: Chantal Akerman's Hyperrealist Everyday|date=1996|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham|isbn=9780822317265|page=32}}</ref> [[Deleuze]] and [[Guattari]] write about the concept of minor literature as being characterized by the following things: *1. Minor literature is the literature that a [[minority group|minority]] makes in a major language; the language is effected by a strong co-efficient of [[deterritorialization]]. *2. Every individual matter is immediately plugged into political because minor literature exists in a narrow space. *3. Everything has a collective value: what the solitary writer says already has collective value.<ref name="What Is A Minor Literature">{{cite journal|last1=Deleuze|first1=Gilles|last2=Guattari|first2=Félix|last3=Brinkley|first3=Robert|title=What Is A Minor Literature?|journal=Mississippi Review|date=1983|volume=3|issue=1}}</ref>
[[Deleuze]] and [[Guattari]] claim that these characteristics describe the revolutionary conditions within the canon of literature.<ref name="What Is A Minor Literature"/> Akerman has referenced [[Deleuze]] and [[Guattari]] on how, in minor literature, the characters assume an immediate, nonhierarchical relation between small individual matters and economic, commercial, juridical, and political ones.<ref name="Duke University Press"/> While the filmmaker has an interest in multiple [[deterritorialization]]s, she also considers the feminist demand for the exercise of [[Identity (social science)|identity]], where a borderline status may be an undesirable position.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Marguilles|first1=Ivonne|title=Nothing Happens: Chantal Akerman's Hyperrealist Everyday|date=1996|publisher=Duke University Press|location=Durham|isbn=9780822317265|page=25}}</ref>
===Feminism===
Akerman has used the setting of a kitchen to explore the intersection between femininity and domesticity.<ref name="New York Times">{{cite news|last1=Donadio|first1=Rachel|title=The Director's Director: Chantal Akerman|publisher=New York Times|date=25 March 2016}}</ref> The kitchens in Akerman's work provide intimate spaces for connection and conversation and serve the function of a backdrop to the dramas of daily life.<ref name="New York Times"/> The kitchens, alongside other domestic spaces, act as self-confining prisons under patriarchal conditions.<ref name="New York Times"/> In Akerman's work, the kitchen acts as a domestic theatre.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Akerman|first1=Chantal|last2=Sultan|first2=Terrie|title=Chantal Akerman: Moving Through Time and Space|date=2008|publisher=Distributed Art Publishers|location=Bluffer Gallery, Art Museum of the University of Houston|page=7}}</ref>
Although Akerman is often grouped within feminist and queer thinking, the filmmaker has articulated her distance from an essentialist feminism.<ref name="Duke University Press"/> Akerman resists labels relating to her identity like "female", "Jewish" and "lesbian", choosing instead to immerse herself in the identity of being a daughter; Akerman has stated that she sees film as a "generative field of freedom from the boundaries of identity".<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The filmmaker has advocated for multiplicity of expression, explaining that "when people say there is a feminist film language, it is like saying there is only one way for women to express themselves".<ref name="Duke University Press"/> The filmmaker asserted that there are as many cinematic languages as there are individuals.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Writer and scholar Ivone Marguiles notes that Akerman's resistance to be categorized is in response to the rigidity of cinema's earlier essentialist realism and "indicates an awareness of the project of a transhistorical and transcultural feminist aesthetics of the cinema".<ref name="Duke University Press"/>
Akerman works with the feminist motto of the personal being political, complicating it by an investigation of representational links between private and public.<ref name="Duke University Press"/> In Jeanne Dielman, Akerman's most well-known film, the main protagonist does not supply a transparent, accurate representation of a fixed social reality.<ref name="Duke University Press"/> Throughout the film, the housewife and prostitute Jeanne is revealed to be a construct, with multiple historical, social, and cinematic resonances.<ref name="Duke University Press"/>
Akerman engages with realist representations, a form which is historically grounded to act as a feminist gesture and simultaneously as an "irritant" to fixed categories of "woman".<ref name="Duke University Press"/>
===Later career=== In 1991, Akerman was a member of the jury at the [[41st Berlin International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/1991/04_jury_1991/04_Jury_1991.html |title=Berlinale: 1991 Juries |work=berlinale.de |accessdate=2011-03-21}}</ref> In 2011, she joined the full-time faculty of the MFA Program in Media Arts Production at the [[City College of New York]] as a distinguished lecturer and the first Michael & Irene Ross Visiting Professor of Film/Video & Jewish Studies.<ref>{{cite web |title=Chantal Akerman feature is tapped for New York Film Festival {{!}} The City College of New York |url=https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/news/chantal-akerman-ny_film-fesrtival |website=www.ccny.cuny.edu |date=18 September 2015}}</ref>
==Exhibitions== Important solo exhibitions of Akerman's work have been held at the Museum for Contemporary Art, Antwerp, Belgium (2012), MIT, Cambridge Massachusetts (2008), the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, Israel (2006); [[Princeton University Art Museum]], Princeton, NJ (2006); and the [[Centre Georges Pompidou]], Paris (2003). Akerman has participated in [[Documenta]] XI (2002) and the [[Venice Biennale]] (2001).
In 2011, a film retrospective of Akerman's work was shown at the Austrian Film Museum.<ref name=gallery>{{cite web |url=http://www.mariangoodman.com/artists/chantal-akerman/ |title=Chantal Akerman |website=Marian Goodman Gallery}}</ref>
The 2015 Venice Biennale included an installation of interspersed parallel screens displaying the landscape-in-motion footage that would appear in "No Home Movie".
In 2018, the [[Jewish Museum (Manhattan)|Jewish Museum]] presented her final video installation ''NOW'' (2015) in the exhibition ''Scenes from the Collection'', and acquired her work for the collection.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://thejewishmuseum.org/exhibitions/scenes-from-the-collection|title=Scenes from the Collection|website=The Jewish Museum|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref>
==Cinematography==
Akerman's cinematography is characterized by the dryness of language, the lack of metaphorical associations, the composition in a series of discontinuous blocks, the interest in putting a poor, withered syntax and reduced vocabulary at the service of a new intensity.<ref name="What Is A Minor Literature"/> Many directors have cited Akerman's films as an influence on their work.<ref name="New York Times"/> [[Kelly Reichardt]], [[Gus Van Sant]], and [[Sofia Coppola]] have noted their exploration of filming in real time as a tribute to Akerman.<ref name="New York Times"/>
Terrie Sultan, art historian, claims that Akerman's "narrative is marked by an almost Proustian attention to detail and visual grace".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Akerman|first1=Chantal|last2=Sultan|first2=Terrie|title=Chantal Akerman: Moving Through Time and Space|date=2008|publisher=Distributed Art Publishers|location=Bluffer Gallery, Art Museum of the University of Houston|page=26}}</ref> Similarly, Akerman's visual language resists easy categorization and summarization: the filmmaker creates narrative through filmic syntax instead of plot development.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite book|last1=Akerman|first1=Chantal|last2=David|first2=Catherine|last3=Michael|first3=Tarantino|title=Bordering On Fiction: Chantal Akerman's D'Est|date=1995|publisher=New York: Distribured Art Publishers|location=Minneapolis, Walker Art Center|page=54}}</ref>
Akerman was influenced by European art cinema, as well as structuralist film.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Structuralist film used formalist experimentation to propose a reciprocal relationship between image and viewer.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Akerman cites [[Michael Snow]] as a structuralist inspiration, especially his film Wavelength, which is composed of a single shot of a photograph of a sea on a loft wall, with the camera slowly zooming in.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Akerman was drawn to the perceived dullness of structuralism because it rejected the dominant cinema's concern for plot.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> As a teenager in Brussels, Akerman skipped school in order to see movies, including films from the experimental festival in Knokke-le-Zoute.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Akerman addresses the voyeurism that is always present within cinematic discourse by often playing a character within her films, thus placing herself on both sides of the camera simultaneously.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The filmmaker used the boredom of structuralism in order to generate a bodily feeling in the viewer, accentuating the passage of time.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Akerman's filming style relies on capturing ordinary life. By encouraging viewers to have patience for a slower pace, her films emphasize the humanity of the everyday.<ref name="ReferenceC"/> Kathy Halbreich states that the filmmaker "creates a cinema of waiting, of passages, of resolutions deferred".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Akerman|first1=Chantal|last2=David|first2=Catherine|last3=Michael|first3=Tarantino|title=Bordering On Fiction: Chantal Akerman's D'Est|date=1995|publisher=New York: Distribured Art Publishers|location=Minneapolis, Walker Art Center|page=26}}</ref>
Many of Akerman's films portray the movement of people across distances or their absorption with claustrophobic spaces.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> Curator Jon Davies states that Akerman's domestic interiors "conceal gendered labour and violence, secrecy and shame, where traumas both large and small unfold with few, if any witnesses".<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
==Death== Akerman died on 5 October 2015 in Paris; ''[[Le Monde]]'' reported that she committed [[suicide]].<ref name=monde>{{cite news|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/cinema/article/2015/10/06/la-cineaste-chantal-akerman-est-morte_4783566_3476.html|author=Isabelle Regnier|title=La cinéaste Chantal Akerman est morte|publisher=''Le Monde''|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref> She was 65.<ref name=nytobit>{{cite news|last1=Donadio|first1=Rachel|last2=Buckley|first2=Clara|title=Chantal Akerman, Pioneering Belgian Filmmaker, Dies at 65|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/07/arts/chantal-akerman-belgian-filmmaker-dies-65.html?_r=0|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015|publisher=''The New York Times''}}</ref><ref name=liberation>{{cite news|url=http://next.liberation.fr/culture-next/2015/10/06/mort-de-la-cineaste-chantal-akerman_1398190|author=Julien Gester|title=Mort de la cinéaste Chantal Akerman|publisher=''Libération''|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref><ref name=guardian>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/oct/06/chantal-akerman-pioneering-belgium-film-director-and-theorist-dies-aged-65|author=Catherine Shoard|title=Chantal Akerman, pioneering Belgian film director and theorist, dies aged 65|publisher=''Guardian''|date=6 October 2015|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref> Her last film was the documentary ''[[No Home Movie]]'', a series of conversations with her mother shortly before her mother's death; of the film, she said, "I think if I knew I was going to do this, I wouldn't have dared to do it."<ref name="NYT">{{Citation | last =Rapold | first =Nicolas | title =Chantal Akerman Takes Emotional Path in Film About 'Maman' | publisher =''The New York Times'' | date =5 August 2015 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/arts/international/chantal-akerman-takes-emotional-path-in-film-about-maman.html | accessdate = 24 November 2015}}</ref>
According to Akerman's sister, she had recently been hospitalized for [[Major depressive disorder|depression]], before returning home to Paris ten days prior her death.<ref name=nytobit />

[[Image:Croquis.jpg|thumb|right|Croquis drawing of a woman]] '''Croquis''' drawing is quick and [[sketch (drawing)|sketch]]y [[drawing]] of a live [[Model (art)|model]]. Croquis drawings are usually made in a few minutes, after which the model changes pose or leaves and another croquis is drawn.
The short duration of the pose benefits models because they do not need to keep still for a long time; this also benefits the artists because it helps them concentrate on the essential elements of the pose, or the most important parts of the drawing. An artist does not have time to draw all the details, so they learn to concentrate on the important elements. Croquis is also a good method of drawing subjects that generally do not stand still and pose, such as insects, [[animal]]s, and [[child]]ren.
After the initial sketch, croquis drawing can be used as a foundation for another work of art such as a [[painting]] or may be used as a work of art itself.
The word ''croquis'' comes from [[French language|French]] and means simply "sketch".
In [[fashion]], the term refers to a quick sketch of a figure (typically nine heads tall as this is the accepted proportions for [[fashion illustration]]) with a loose drawing of the clothes that are being designed. Often a large number of croquis drawings will be created for one finished look, which is fully drawn and finished.
==References== {{Unreferenced|date=February 2008}}
{{Art-stub}}
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Drawing]]

{{Primary sources|date=December 2015}}
The '''Danish Design Award''' is an annual international design prize awarded by the member organization Design denmark and [[Danish Design Centre]] in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]. Danish Design Award demonstrates the value and impact of design in Denmark today and inspires and stimulates the use of design and design thinking in companies and society.
The new partnership behind the Danish Design Award brings together the design industry and the entire country around an annual design event celebrating the difference design can make.
Fifty years ago, in 1965, the first Danish design award, the ID Prize was launched. This was followed by the IG Prize in 1980, which merged, into the Danish Design Award in 2000.
Now, the Danish Design Award is presented in a new version as a joint creation from the Danish Design Centre and the alliance of design professionals, Design denmark.
Danish Design Award encompasses all disciplines within the realm of design and adopts a three-dimensional focus on form, function and value creation.
The fifteen award categories range from design that has created jobs or cut costs over health solutions and resource sharing to visionary concepts demonstrating the wide range and diversity of the capability of design to bring added value.
== History == ;1965 - Industrial Design Prize Acknowledging the best in [[Danish design]] with an annual award began in 1965. At that time the award was called the {{Interlanguage link multi|ID Prize|da|3=ID Prisen}}.<ref name="en.ddc.dk">{{cite web |url=http://en.ddc.dk/article/more-40-years-design-awards |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100122184254/http://en.ddc.dk/article/more-40-years-design-awards |dead-url=yes |archive-date=22 January 2010 |first=Pia Dandanell |last=Parrot |title=More than 40 Years of Design Awards |publisher=Danish Design Center |date=30 September 2008 |accessdate=28 December 2010 |df= }}</ref> Danish design had become an important concept, not just in Scandinavia but worldwide. Danish design represented - and continues to represent - simple, pure and aesthetic design with a clear user focus.<ref name="en.ddc.dk"/>
;1980 – Industrial Graphic Design Prize In 1980 the ID Prize had a sister award, the {{Interlanguage link multi|IG Prize|da|3=IG Prisen}}, which celebrated the best industrial graphic design.
;2000 – The Danish Design Prize In 2000, the ID Prize and the IG Prize merged to become the Danish Design Prize. With the brief pause in 2005 and 2006, the Danish Design Prize 2007 marked an anniversary for Danish design: the design prizes were awarded for the fortieth time.
;2007 – The Designmatters Award A new introduction in 2007 was the Designmatters Award. This award goes to a small or medium-sized company that has made a serious effort to incorporate design and achieved a positive effect on the bottom line. The first recipient of the Designmatters Award was the lighting company Lightyears.<ref name="en.ddc.dk"/>
== Award Winners == Source: <ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ddc.dk/page/vindere-af-den-danske-designpris-2000-2009 | title=Vindere of Den Danske Designpris 2000-2009 | language=da | publisher=Danish Design Center | accessdate=28 December 2010 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120313064615/http://www.ddc.dk/page/vindere-af-den-danske-designpris-2000-2009 | archivedate=13 March 2012}}</ref> * Pelikan Design * [[Timothy Jacob Jensen]], Jacob Jensen Design * Hansens Flødeis<ref>[http://www.hansensicecream.com/ Hansens Ice Cream website]</ref> * [[BC Lift]]<ref>[http://www.bclift.com/Design-prize.132.aspx BC Lift website]</ref> * Thomas Pedersen, [[Fredericia Furniture]]<ref>[http://www.fredericia.com/show.asp?lang=uk&s=newspress&i2=83 "Stingray Elected 'Contemporary Classic of the Year,' Fredericia Furniture website, 10/13/09.] Accessed 12/28/10.</ref> * [[GN ReSound]] * [[Foss (company)|Foss]] * [[Hatch & Bloom]] * [[Kursiv]] * [[Cecilie Manz]] * [[Kontrapunkt AS]] strategic design and brand agency.<ref>http://www.kontrapunkt.com/en/news/archive/apoteker-pris/</ref> * Christian Flindt, [[Paustian]] * [[Scandinavian DesignLab]] * [[Mogens Holm-Rasmussen]] * [[Hald Engel]] * [[e-Types]] * CPH Design * Torpe&Kolsch * 3Part * Grundfos<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.grundfos.dk/web/homehandg.nsf/Webopslag/552EF133AB790938C1257299002EE40B | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719124348/https://www.grundfos.dk/web/homehandg.nsf/Webopslag/552EF133AB790938C1257299002EE40B | title=Denmark | publisher=Grundfos | archivedate=19 July 2011}} </ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Delores E. Churchill.jpg|thumb|220px|Delores Churchill with a partially woven basketry hat]] '''Delores E. Churchill''' is a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] [[artist]] of [[Haida people|Haida]] descent. She is a [[Weaver (occupation)|weaver]] of baskets, hats, robes, and other regalia, as well as leading revitalization efforts for [[Haida language|Haida]], her native language.
==Background== Churchill was born in [[Masset]], [[Queen Charlotte Islands]], Canada in 1929.<ref name="kenai">[http://www.artskenai.com/gallery_detail.asp?ID=208 Delores Churchill.] ''Kenai River Council on The Arts.'' 2003 (retrieved 5 Nov 2009)</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kfsk.org/2015/10/15/haida-master-weaver-delores-churchill-shares-her-story/|title=Haida master weaver Delores Churchill shares her story|last=15|first=Angela Denning {{!}} Oct|last2=2015|date=2015-10-15|website=KFSK|access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref> As a girl, she attended schools that forced her to speak English in place of her native tongue, a typical practice of that time period. She first studied traditional Haida weaving with her mother, [[Selina Peratrovich]], who is also a nationally recognized master weaver. She went on to study traditional [[Tsimshian]] weaving from masters [[Flora Matthew]] and [[Brenda White]].<ref>[http://www.arts.wa.gov/folk-arts/master-artists/churchill-delores.shtml Folk Arts | Master Artist | Delores Churchill<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Churchill further studied at the British Museum and relearned the six-strand weave.<ref name="krbd.org">{{Cite web|url=https://www.krbd.org/2017/05/05/delores-churchill-receives-lifetime-achievement-award/|title=Delores Churchill honored with Lifetime Achievement Award|last=5|first=Maria Dudzak {{!}} May|last2=2017|date=2017-05-05|website=KRBD|access-date=2017-07-27}}</ref> After retiring from a bookkeeping career and raising her family, Churchill turned her attention back to basketry at a time when Haida basket weaving was in serious decline as an art form among younger members of the tribe.<ref name=kenai/> She taught her niece, [[Lisa Telford]], traditional Haida basket weaving.
==Artwork== Churchill is known for her utilitarian and ceremonial objects that often use spruce root, cedar bark, wool, and [[natural dye]]s. Some of her artwork is displayed at the [[Totem Heritage Center]] in [[Ketchikan, Alaska|Ketchikan]], [[Alaska]], where she has also taught courses in basketry.<ref>http://www.city.ketchikan.ak.us/departments/museums/documents/InstructorBiosforweb.pdf</ref>
== Haida language revitalization == As one of the few remaining native speakers of [[Haida language|Haida]], Churchill has fought to share her linguistic heritage. Canada and the United States both suppressed use of the Haida language, especially through forcing Native children to speak English in [[Indian residential schools|boarding schools]]. Churchill was forced by her teachers in the [[Canadian Indian residential school system|Canadian residential school]] she attended as a child to speak English and was punished for speaking her own language. Despite these challenges, Churchill has remained adamant in her desire to preserve her native language and frequently works with Haida children and assisted her daughter April Churchill's language revitalization.<ref>{{cite web |title=Northern Northwest Coast Weavers |url=http://www.burkemuseum.org/static/baskets/artists/nnwc.html |publisher=Burke Museum |accessdate=11 July 2018 |date=2001}}</ref>
== Honors and awards == Churchill is the recipient of numerous awards, including: * National Heritage Fellowship Award, ''[[National Endowment for the Arts]]''<ref>http://www.nea.gov/about/NEARTS/15-2007vol1/15p5churchill.html</ref> * Lifetime Achievement Award, ''Central Council of Tlingit and Haida Indian Tribes of Alaska''<ref name="krbd.org"/> * Alaska State Council on the Arts fellowship<ref name="krbd.org"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}
