revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | embed = | honorific_prefix = | name = Elena Anatolievna Gremina | honorific_suffix = | image = Elena Gremina.jpg | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = Elena Gremina in 2015 | native_name = Елена Анатольевна Гремина | native_name_lang = Russian | pseudonym = | birth_name = Elena Anatolievna Grebnav | birth_date = {{Birth date|1956|11|20|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2018|05|16|1956|10|20|df=y}} | death_place = Moscow, Russia | resting_place = | occupation = Writer, [[playwright]] | language = [[Russian language|Russian]] | residence = Moscow, Russia | nationality = Russian | alma_mater = [[Maxim Gorky Literature Institute]] | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = {{ill|Mikhail Ugarov|ru|Угаров, Михаил Юрьевич}} 1993–2018 | relatives = {{ill|Anatoly Grebnev|ru|Гребнев, Анатолий Борисович}} (father)
[[Galina Mindadze]] (mother) | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = 1983–2018 }} '''Elena Anatolievna Gremina''' (20 November 1956{{snd}}16 May 2018) was a Russian writer and playwright who was one of the founders of the factual theatre {{ill|Teatr.doc|ru|Театр.doc}}. ==Early life== Elena Grebnav was born on 20 November 1956 in [[Moscow]], [[Soviet Union]], to Georgian translator [[Galina Mindadze]] and [[playwright]] {{ill|Anatoly Grebnev|ru|Гребнев, Анатолий Борисович}}. At an early age, Elena would write protests in verse, such as an early piece about children being prevented from seeing a film. She later adopted the surname Gremina, a combination of her parent's surnames so as to be able to write without being compared to her them. Gremina studied at the [[Maxim Gorky Literature Institute]] to become a playwright. ==Career== Grebnav's first production took place in 1983, but only came to prominence in the 1990s after her plays were performed at the [[Moscow Pushkin Drama Theatre]] and she won awards from [[Westdeutscher Rundfunk]]. A favoured subject matter of Grebnav in this period was conflicted women of history. Grebnav married {{ill|Mikhail Ugarov|ru|Угаров, Михаил Юрьевич}} in 1993. Together with her husband and father, she created the television series, ''{{ill|St. Petersburg Secrets|ru|Петербургские тайны}}''. After being influenced by [[Elyse Dodgson]] at the [[Royal Court Theatre]], London, Gremina and her husband founded {{ill|Teatr.doc|ru|Театр.doc}}. When they heard Dodgson talk about the use of verbatim techniques in theatre to present factual stories on the stage, they decided that it was a way to reconnect Russian theatre with the public in their home country.{{cite news |last1=Dugdale |first1=Sasha |title=Elena Gremina obituary |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2018/may/24/elena-gremina-obituary |accessdate=3 June 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=24 May 2018}} The duo started Teatr.doc in 2002, and soon began to present performances based on current events.{{cite book |last1=Senelick |first1=Lawrence |title=Historical Dictionary of Russian Theatre |date=2015 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |location=Lanham |isbn=978-1-44224-927-1 |page=464 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=mx5lCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA485&lpg=PA485&dq=%22Elena+Gremina%22&source=bl&ots=x-mSztUWr4&sig=JUNRZhH5XOXKSlzN-i2CHnUiPWw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjJmdaEz7fbAhWnJcAKHRhEDqE4FBDoAQhRMAg#v=onepage&q=%22Elena%20Gremina%22&f=false}} The performances became more political in nature, which resulted in Gremina and her husband being visited by the police and having equipment confiscated. One such piece written by Gremina was on the death of [[Sergei Magnitsky]], an anticorruption [[lawyer]]. After a police raid of Teatr.doc in 2015 that saw three members of the production temporarily arrested and sets destroyed, Gremina was summoned to the [[Ministry of Culture (Russia)|Ministry of Culture]] where she was threatened with further raids.{{cite news |last1=Ruble |first1=Blair A. |title=Putin's Punitive Theatre of the Absurd |url=http://www.newsweek.com/putins-punitive-theater-absurd-298179 |accessdate=3 June 2018 |work=Newsweek |date=1 September 2015}} Ugarov died following a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] in April 2018.{{cite news |title=Russian playwright found dead after making play about anti-corruption lawyer Sergei Magnitsky |url=http://nationalpost.com/news/world/russian-playwright-found-dead-after-making-play-about-anti-corruption-lawyer-sergei-magnitsky |accessdate=3 June 2018 |work=National Post |date=16 May 2018}} Gremina died six weeks later, also from a heart attack. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gremina, Elena}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:People from Moscow]] [[Category:20th-century Russian women writers]] [[Category:21st-century Russian women writers]] [[Category:Russian political writers]] [[Category:Women television writers]] [[Category:Deaths from heart failure]] [[Category:Women theatre managers and producers]]

[[File:Amulettes phalliques gallo-romaines Musée Saint-Remi 120208.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Gallo-Roman]] examples of the ''fascinum'' in bronze. The topmost is an example of the "fist and phallus" amulet with a ''manus fica''.]] [[File:Pompeji Penis Sign.jpg|thumb|150px|Phallus inscribed on a paving stone at [[Pompeii]]]]
In [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]] and [[Magic in the Graeco-Roman world|magic]], the '''''fascinus''''' or '''''fascinum''''' was the embodiment of the divine [[phallus]]. The word can refer to the deity himself ('''Fascinus'''), to phallus [[effigy|effigies]] and [[amulet]]s, and to the spells used to invoke his divine protection.<ref>The [[grammatical gender|neuter]] form ''fascinum'' is used most often for objects or magic charms, masculine ''fascinus'' for the god.</ref> [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]] calls it a ''medicus invidiae'', a "doctor" or remedy for envy (''[[invidia]]'', a "looking upon") or the [[evil eye]].
==Etymology== The English word "[[wikt:fascinate|fascinate]]" ultimately derives from Latin ''[[wikt:fascinum|fascinum]]'' and the related verb ''fascinare'', "to use the power of the ''fascinus''", that is, "to practice magic" and hence "to enchant, bewitch" [[Catullus]] uses the verb at the end of ''Carmen 7'', a [[hendecasyllable|hendecasyllabic]] poem addressing his lover Lesbia; he expresses his infinite desire for kisses that cannot be counted by voyeurs nor "fascinated" (put under a spell) by a malicious tongue; such bliss, as also in ''Carmen'' 5, potentially attracts ''invidia''.<ref>David Wray, [https://books.google.com/books?id=6Qg3kYF-WS4C&pg=PA152&dq=fascinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=14#v=onepage&q=fascinus&f=false ''Catullus and the Poetics of Roman Manhood''] (Cambridge University Press, 2001), p. 152.</ref>
[[Fescennine Verses]], the satiric and often lewd songs or chants performed on various social occasions, may have been so-named from the ''fascinum''; ancient sources propose this etymology along with an alternative origin from [[Fescennia]], a small town in [[Etruria]].<ref>Gian Biagio Conte, [https://books.google.com/books?id=NJGp_dkXnuUC&pg=PA23&dq=fascinum&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=172#v=onepage&q=fascinum&f=false ''Latin Literature: A History''] (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1987, 1994), p. 23.</ref>
==Public religion== [[File:Tintinnabulum Pompeii MAN Napoli Inv27839.jpg|thumb|upright|150px|Fascinus from Pompeii showing a phallus]] The [[Vestal Virgin]]s tended the cult of the ''fascinus [[SPQR|populi Romani]]'', the sacred image of the phallus that was one of the tokens of the safety of the state ''(sacra Romana)''. It was thus associated with the [[Palladium (classical antiquity)|Palladium]].<ref>R. Joy Littlewood, ''A [[Commentary (philology)|Commentary]] on [[Ovid]]:'' Fasti ''Book 6'' (Oxford University Press, 2006), p. 73; [[T.P. Wiseman]], ''Remus: A Roman Myth'' (Cambridge University Press, 1995), p. 61 [https://books.google.com/books?id=7LPNHRUlWacC&pg=PA61&dq=fascinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=68#v=onepage&q=fascinus&f=false online.]</ref> [[Roman mythology|Roman myths]], such as the begetting of [[Servius Tullius]], suggest that this phallus was an embodiment of a masculine generative power located within the hearth, regarded as sacred.<ref>Joseph Rykwert, ''The Idea of a Town: The Anthropology of Urban Form in Rome, Italy, and the Ancient World'' (MIT Press, 1988), pp. 101 and 159 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Jq78Ff2TYHAC&pg=PA159&dq=fascinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=2#v=onepage&q=fascinus&f=false online.]</ref> When a general celebrated a [[Roman triumph|triumph]], the Vestals hung an effigy of the ''fascinus'' on the underside of his [[chariot]] to protect him from ''invidia''.<ref>[[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]], ''Natural History'' 28.4.7 (28.39).</ref>
[[Augustine of Hippo|Augustine]], whose primary source on Roman religion was the lost theological works of [[Marcus Terentius Varro]], notes that a phallic image was carried in procession annually at the festival of [[Liber|Father Liber]], the Roman god [[interpretatio graeca|identified with]] [[Dionysus|Dionysus or Bacchus]], for the purpose of protecting the fields from ''fascinatio'', magic compulsion:<ref>[[Augustine of Hippo]], ''[[City of God (book)|De civitate Dei]]'' 7.21; Williams, ''Roman Homosexuality'', p. 92.</ref> {{quote|Varro says that certain rites of Liber were celebrated in Italy which were of such unrestrained wickedness that the shameful parts of the male were worshipped at crossroads in his honour. … For, during the days of the [[Liberalia|festival of Liber]], this obscene member, placed on a little trolley, was first exhibited with great honour at the crossroads in the countryside, and then conveyed into the city itself. … In this way, it seems, the god Liber was to be propitiated, in order to secure the growth of seeds and to repel enchantment ''(fascinatio)'' from the fields.<ref>English translation by R.W. Dyson, ''Augustine: The City of God against the Pagans'' (Cambridge University Press, 1998, 2002), p. 292 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ReU2M8cLtGcC&pg=PA292&dq=%2221+Of+the+wickedness+of+the+rites+celebrated+in+honour+of+Liber%22&lr=&as_drrb_is=q&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=&as_brr=3&cd=1#v=onepage&q=%2221%20Of%20the%20wickedness%20of%20the%20rites%20celebrated%20in%20honour%20of%20Liber%22&f=false online.]</ref>}} As a divinized phallus, Fascinus shared attributes with [[Mutunus Tutunus]], whose shrine was supposed to date from the [[Founding of Rome|founding of the city]], and the imported Greek god [[Priapus]].<ref>[[Arnobius]], ''Adversus nationes'' 4.7, explicitly connects Tutunus to the ''fascinus''; see [[Robert E.A. Palmer]], "Mutinus Titinus: A Study in Etrusco-Roman Religion and Topography," in ''Roman Religion and Roman Empire: Five Essays'' (University of Pennsylvania Press, 1974), pp. 187–206.</ref>
==As a magic symbol== Phallic charms, often winged, were ubiquitous in Roman culture, appearing as objects of jewellery such as pendants and finger rings, relief carvings, lamps, and wind chimes (''[[Tintinnabulum|tintinnabula]]'').<ref name='CAW'>{{cite book |author1=Williams, C. A. |date=1999 |title=Roman Homosexuality: Ideologies of Masculinity in Classical Antiquity |publisher=City University of New York |page=92}}</ref><ref name='SorS'>{{cite book |author1=[[Catherine Johns|Johns, C.]] |date=1982 |title=Sex or Symbol? Erotic Images of Greece and Rome |publisher=British Museum Press |place=London}}</ref><ref name='TRAC'>{{Cite book |author1=Parker, A. |date=2018 |chapter=The Bells! The Bells! Approaching ''tintinnabula'' in Roman Britain and Beyond |editor1=Parker, A. |editor2=Mckie, S. |title=Material Approaches to Roman Magic: Occult Objects and Supernatural Substances |series=[[Theoretical Roman Archaeology Conference|TRAC]] Themes in Roman Archaeology 2 |place=Oxford |publisher=Oxbow |pages=57–68}}</ref> ''Fascinus'' was thought particularly to ward off evil from children, mainly boys, and from conquering generals. The protective function of the phallus is usually related to the virile and regenerative powers of an erected phallus, though in most cases the emotion, shame, or laughter created by obscenity is the power that diverts the evil eye.<ref name='Dasen'>{{cite book |author1=Dasen, V. |date=2015 |chapter=Pobaskania: Amulets and Magic in Antiquity |editor1=Boschung, D. |editor2=Bremmer, J. N. |title=The Materiality of Magic |series=Morphomata 20 |pages= 177–204}}</ref>
There are very few Roman images of people wearing a phallic charm.<ref name='Dasen' /> Varro notes the custom of hanging a phallic charm on a baby's neck,{{efn|Varro, ''On the Latin language'', VII.97}} and examples have been found of phallus-bearing rings too small to be worn except by children.<ref name='Henig'>Martin Henig, ''Religion in Roman Britain'' (London: BT Batsford LTD, 1984), pp. 185–186 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZOhxSp8nlPsC&pg=PA186&dq=%22A+child's+gold+ring+with+phallus%22&hl=en&ei=1tOTTIXKG4TfnAenpYCRCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22A%20child's%20gold%20ring%20with%20phallus%22&f=false online], with image of example.</ref> A 2017 [[experimental archaeology]] project suggested that some types of phallic pendant were designed to remain pointing outwards, in the direction of travel of the wearer, in order to face towards any potential danger or bad luck and nullify it before it could affect the wearer.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Whitmore, A. |date=2017 |chapter=Fascinating ''fascina'': apotropaic magic and how to wear a penis |editor1=Cifarelli, M. |editor2=Gawlinkski, L. |title=What shall I say of clothes? Theoretical and Methodological Approaches to the Study of Dress in Antiquity |place=Boston, MA |publisher=[[American Institute of Archaeology]] |pages=47–65}}</ref> Other symbols may have been interchangeable with the phallus, such as the club of [[Hercules]].<ref name='Dasen' />
The victory of the phallus over the power of the evil eye may be represented by the phallus ejaculating towards a disembodied eye. This motif is shown in several examples of Roman art.<ref>Daniel Ogden, ''Magic, Witchcraft, and Ghosts in the Greek and Roman Worlds: A Sourcebook'' (Oxford University Press, 2002), p. 225 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ox3QRxWQQtcC&pg=PA225&dq=fascinus&lr=&as_drrb_is=b&as_minm_is=0&as_miny_is=1988&as_maxm_is=0&as_maxy_is=2010&num=100&as_brr=3&cd=6#v=onepage&q=fascinus&f=false online.]</ref> For example, the motif is known from multiple [[relief|relief sculptures]] from [[Leptis Magna]] in present-day [[Libya]],<ref name='SorS' /> as well as several instances on [[Hadrian's Wall]].<ref name='BAR'>{{cite book |author1=Parker, A. |date=2017 |chapter=Protecting the Troops? Phallic Carvings in the North of Roman Britain |editor1=Parker, A |title=''Ad Vallum'': Papers on the Roman Army and Frontiers in celebration of Dr [[Brian Dobson (archaeologist)|Brian Dobson]] |series=BAR British Series 631 |place=Oxford |publisher=British Archaeological Report |pages=117–130}}</ref> A 1st-century BC [[terracotta]] figurine shows "two little phallus-men sawing an eyeball in half."<ref name='CAW' /><ref name='SorS' />
The "fist and phallus" amulet was prevalent amongst soldiers. These are phallic pendants with a representation of a (usually) clenched fist at the bottom of the shaft, facing away from the [[glans]]. Several examples show the fist making the ''manus fica'' or "[[fig sign]]", a symbol of good luck.<ref name='Henig' /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://finds.org.uk/database/search/results/q/LIN-2BE126 |publisher=Portable Antiquities Scheme |title=PAS Record: LIN-2BE126 |accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> The largest known collection comes from [[Camulodunum]].<ref>{{cite book |author1=Crummy, N. |title=Colchester Archaeological Report 2: The Roman Small finds from excavations in Colchester 1971-9 |place=Colchester |publisher=Colchester Archaeological Trust |date=1983}}</ref> Some examples of the fist-and-phallus amulets incorporate [[vulva]]te imagery as well as an extra [[Apotropaic magic|apotropaic]] device.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Parker, A. |date=2015 |title=The Fist-and-Phallus Pendants from Roman Catterick |journal=Britannia |volume=46 |pages=135–149 |doi=10.1017/S0068113X15000161}}</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px"> File:Tintinnabulum-Fund in Herculaneum.jpg|A ''[[Tintinnabulum (Ancient Rome)|tintinnabulum]]'' from [[Herculaneum]] (Italy), with the phallus as a beast which the human male engages in combat. File:Bas-relief of fascinus.jpg|Bas-relief of a legged phallus ejaculating into an [[evil eye]] on which a scorpion sits, from [[Leptis Magna]] (Libya). File:Yorkshire Museum, York (Eboracum) (7685630354).jpg|A simple phallic relief from ''[[Eboracum]]'' (York, UK). File:KENT-E3D152 (FindID 392891).jpg|A phallic pendant from Kent (UK). File:Roman_phallic_pendant_(FindID_156232).jpg|A simple phallic pendant from Suffolk (UK). </gallery>
==Notes== {{notelist}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{commonscat|Fascinum}} *[https://archive.org/stream/dictionaryofgree00smituoft#page/520/mode/2up Open Library: Dictionary of Greek and Roman antiquities: Fascinum]

revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=December 2016}} {{Engvar|date=December 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Gamer | image = Gaamerfilm.jpeg | alt = | caption = | director = [[Oleg Sentsov]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Oleg Sentsov * Olga Zhurzhenko }} | writer = {{Plainlist| * Oleg Sentsov }} | starring = {{Plainlist| * Vladislav Zhuk }} | music = | cinematography = Egor Petrik
Eugene Vradiy
Gennady Veselkov | editing = Dmitry Kundryutsky | production companies = {{Plainlist| * Cry Cinema }} | distributor = | released = 2011 | runtime = 92 minutes | country = [[Ukraine]] | language = Russian
Ukrainian | budget = $20 000[http://www.ivi.ru/watch/107521/box Гамep] | gross = $2 696 }} '''Gamer''' ({{lang-uk|Гамep}}), alternatively spelt '''''Gámer'''''[http://time.com/4010879/russia-oleg-sentsov-gamer-ukrainian-filmmaker/ "Russia Sentences Ukrainian Filmmaker Oleg Sentsov to 20 Years in Prison"] by Joanna Plucinska. ''Time'', 26 August 2015. or '''''Gaamer''''',[https://www.opendemocracy.net/od-russia/mike-downey/%e2%80%98bright-future%e2%80%99-of-oleg-sentsov "The 'bright future' of Oleg Sentsov"] by Mike Downey. ''Open Democracy'', 17 February 2015.[http://www.rferl.org/a/ukraine-filmmaker-sentsov-jailed/25436572.html "Ukrainian Filmmaker Remains Behind Bars Despite Growing Support"] by Lilya Palveleva. ''Radio Free Europe'', 26 June 2014. was a debut feature-length film directed by [[Oleg Sentsov]]. It was released in Russian and Ukrainian language{{cite web|url=http://ukrkino.ru/2012/06/gamer-ukraina-2011/|title=Гамер 2011|publisher=}} in 2011. He tells of a young [[gamer]], who lives with his mother in [[Simferopol]]. The premiere was held in 2012 in [[Rotterdam]]. The film participated in several international film festivals and was a highly marked by the professional community,{{cite web|url=http://www.kinoart.ru/blogs/wiesbaden|title=Западно-восточный диван. GoEast, Висбаден-2012|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://kinoart.ru/archive/2012/05/tsivilizatsiya-v-gamer-tajme|title=Цивилизация в гамер-тайме. «Гамер», режиссер Олег Сенцов|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.unian.ua/politics/940499-na-odeskomu-kinofestivali-pokazali-film-gamer-na-pidtrimku-kinorejisera-sentsova.html|title=На Одеському кінофестивалі показали фільм «Гамер» на підтримку кінорежисера Сенцова|publisher=}} in particular, a premium [[Russian Guild of Film Critics]] at the festival ''Spirit of Fire'' in [[Khanty-Mansiysk]]. == Plot == The main character in the film is a teenager named Lyoscha - enthusiastic computer games player, spending all his time in special clubs. Following his passion, he almost did not pay attention to others: neither to his mother, who was distressed by the fact that her son had dropped out of studies, nor to his girlfriend Katya, who was in love with him, nor to any of his friends. In an environment of professional gamers Lyoscha becomes one of the best, followed by victories in multiple competitions. In an effort to become the best he embarks on an international gaming tournament in [[Los Angeles]], but he takes only the second place. After returning home, Lyoscha gets rid of his gaming devices, and for the first time during the entire film, a smile appears on his face. == Reception == The film was selected to a number of prestigious international film festivals{{Citation|title=Gámer|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2217809/awards|access-date=2018-08-04}} like Rotterdam and Sao Paulo with some reviewers evoking comparisons with ''400 blows''{{Cite news|url=https://moc.media/en/194|title=Gaamer (Gamer)|access-date=2018-08-04}} and stating that Sentsov "breaks the barrier that separates cinema from real life{{Citation|title=Gaamer|url=https://www.iffrunleashed.com/film/gaamer|language=en|access-date=2018-08-04}}. Its boxoffice in Ukraine at the time was minimal, but the film is still accumulating revenue via its online distribution by Rotterdam Unleashed where it can be watched all over the world. == Cast == * Vladislav Zhuk as Lyosha * Alexander Fedotov as Bur * Zhanna Biryuk as mother == Awards and nominations == *[[São Paulo International Film Festival]] — Best Foreign Film (nom) ==References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|id=2217809|title=Gamer}} * [https://www.iffr.com/en/films/gaamer/ Viewing movie] Online [[International Film Festival Rotterdam]] {{ref-en}} [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Russian-language Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Ukrainian-language films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Teen films]] [[Category:Youth culture]] [[Category:Films set in Ukraine]] [[Category:Films shot in Ukraine]] [[Category:Films about video games]] [[Category:ESports films]] {{videogame-culture-stub}}

{{Infobox film |name = Gang in Blue |image = Ganginblue.jpg |caption = DVD cover |director = [[Melvin Van Peebles]]
[[Mario Van Peebles]] |starring = |producer = Lee Mayes
Neal Moritz |released = {{Film date|1996}} |runtime = 99 minutes |country = United States |language = English }} '''''Gang in Blue''''' is a 1996 American film co-directed by [[Melvin Van Peebles]] and his son, [[Mario Van Peebles]], about a black [[police officer]] who discovers a cell of [[white supremacist]] [[vigilante]]s within his [[police department|department]]. ==Cast== *[[Mario Van Peebles]] as Michael Rhodes *[[Josh Brolin]] as Keith DeBruler *[[Melvin Van Peebles]] as Andre Speier *[[Cynda Williams]] as Anita Boyard *[[Stephen Lang]] as Moose Tavola *[[J. T. Walsh]] as Lt. William Eyler *[[Sean McCann (actor)|Sean McCann]] as Clute Mirkovich *[[Zach Grenier]] as Joe Beckstrem ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0116393|title=Gang in Blue}} {{Mario Van Peebles}} {{Melvin Van Peebles}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gang In Blue}} [[Category:1996 films]] [[Category:1990s crime drama films]] [[Category:American crime drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about race and ethnicity]] [[Category:Films directed by Mario Van Peebles]] [[Category:Films directed by Melvin Van Peebles]] [[Category:Vigilante films]] [[Category:Films about corruption]] {{1990s-crime-drama-film-stub}}

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/91.18.231.78|91.18.231.78]] ([[User talk:91.18.231.78|talk]]): not providing a [[WP:RS|reliable source]] ([[WP:CITE]], [[WP:RS]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{Use South African English|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = Handspring Puppet Company | logo = | caption = | type = [[puppetry]] [[perform]]ance and [[scenic design]] | genre = | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = [[circa]] 1981 | founder = Adrian Kohler and Basil Jones<ref name= "bk"/> | defunct = | location_city = [[Cape Town]] | location_country = [[South Africa]] | location = Locations in [[South Africa]], [[England]], and the [[United States]] | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Thys Stander<ref name="ww"/> | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | traded_as = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.handspringpuppet.co.za/}} | footnotes = | intl = }} The '''Handspring Puppet Company''' is a [[puppetry]] performance and design company established in 1981 by Adrian Kohler and Basil Jones, situated in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]]. Thys Stander is the company's chief puppet maker.<ref name="ww"/>
==History== Jones and Kohler met at the [[Michaelis School of Fine Art]] in Cape Town.<ref>{{cite web|title=About the Company|url=http://www.handspringpuppet.co.za/|work=Handspring Puppet Company|accessdate=4 April 2011}}</ref> At first, they designed puppets for [[target audience|children-targeted]] productions, which Jones initially disliked. Kohler "introduced him [Jones] to the [[west Africa]]n tradition of puppetry for adults,"<ref>{{cite web|last=Costa|first=Maddy|title=The gay puppet stars of Or You Could Kiss Me|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2010/oct/03/gay-puppets-war-horse|work=The Guardian|accessdate=4 April 2011|date=3 October 2010}}</ref> working with Malcolm Purkey and [[Barney Simon]], among others.<ref>{{cite book|last=Baraitser|first=Marion|title=Theatre of Animation: Contemporary Adult Puppet Plays in Context, Volume 10, Part 1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bq6NCRi8P4UC&pg=PA86&dq=handspring+puppet+company&hl=en&ei=2QmaTbrHMqHE0QGcjujoCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-preview-link&resnum=2&ved=0CDUQuwUwATgK#v=onepage&q=handspring%20puppet%20company&f=false|accessdate=4 April 2011|year=1999}}</ref>
== Productions and exhibitions == 1987 saw their exhibition of "Unmasking the Puppet" at [[UNISA]].<ref name= "bk">{{cite book|last=Rubin|first=Don|title=The World Encyclopedia of Contemporary Theatre: Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TIgS_Eij8SEC&pg=PA288&dq=handspring+puppet+company&hl=en&ei=CsWZTa_-Ku-K0QHdzIz5Cw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-preview-link&resnum=5&ved=0CEUQuwUwBA#v=onepage&q=handspring%20puppet%20company&f=false|publisher=Taylor & Francis|accessdate=4 April 2011|year=1997}}</ref> Prior to that, Esther van Ryswyk directed their puppets in a play called ''Episodes of an Easter Rising'' (1985), based on David Lyttons's radio special of the same name.<ref name= "bk"/> It premiered in [[Charleville-Mézières]], [[France]].<ref name="ww">[http://www.playbill.com/celebritybuzz/whoswho/biography/19727 "Handspring Puppet Company"], ''Who's Who'', Celebrity Buzz, accessed 3 April 2011</ref>
In 1997, they worked with [[William Kentridge]] on ''[[Ubu and the Truth Commission]]''.<ref>Kohler and Jones 2007, p. xvii.</ref> It premiered in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]], on 26 May 1997.<ref>The world premiere of ''Ubu and the Truth Commission'' followed on 17 June 1997, at the Kunsfest in [[Weimar]].</ref> Kentridge had been working for some years with the Handspring Puppet Company in Johannesburg, most notably on ''Woyzeck on the Highveld'' in 1993 and ''Faustus in Africa'' in 1996. The latter, according to Kentridge, was "a huge undertaking",<ref>Kentridge 2007, p. ix.</ref> after which he and the company were on the look-out merely for something small to "do and survive".<ref name="Kentridge 2007, p. x">Kentridge 2007, p. x.</ref> Starting on 18 September 1998, ''Ubu and the Truth Commission'' played at the [[Kennedy Center]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], for four performances.<ref>{{cite web|last=McGrath|first=Sean|title=Footloose & Fugard to Highlight D.C.'s Kennedy Center 1998-99 Season|work=Playbill|accessdate=4 April 2011|date=27 August 1998}}</ref>
[[Yaya Coulibaly]]'s play ''Tall Horse'' (2006) toured [[Africa]] under the supervision and direction of the company.<ref>[http://www.handspringpuppet.co.za/html/frameind.html "Tall Horse"]. ''Handsrping Puppet Company''</ref> On 1 March 2011, Kohler and Jones demonstrated a [[hyena]] puppet used in ''Faustus in Africa'' (1995) at the [[TED (conference)|TED 2011]] event in [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], [[California]].<ref name="ted">{{cite web|last=TED Blog|title=The genius puppetry behind War Horse: Handspring Puppet Company|url=http://blog.ted.com/2011/03/30/the-genius-puppetry-behind-war-horse-handspring-puppet-company/|work=TED 2011|accessdate=4 April 2011|date=30 March 2011}}</ref>
The Handspring Puppet Company achieved critical acclaim when ''[[War Horse (play)|War Horse]]'' premiered in [[South Bank, London]], on 17 October 2007.<ref>[http://www.ltdb.co.uk/node/22446 "War Horse"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724023504/http://www.ltdb.co.uk/node/22446 |date=24 July 2011 }} ltdb.co.uk, accessed 20 January 2010.</ref> For this show, Kohler and Jones worked with directors Marianne Elliott and Tom Morris and choreographer [[Toby Sedgwick]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Itzkoff|first=Dave|title=‘War Horse’ Corrals Its American Cast|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/12/20/war-horse-corrals-its-american-cast/?scp=3&sq=war%20horse&st=cse|work=The New York Times|accessdate=14 March 2011|date=20 December 2010}}</ref> to design and construct life-sized horse puppets, controlled by three actors – two to operate the legs and one to control the head and neck, with all three actors providing a variety of sound effects.<ref name="ted"/> The company won an [[Olivier Award]], [[Evening Standard Theatre Award]] and [[London Critics' Circle Theatre Award]].<ref>[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/115735-Hairspray-Wins-Four-2008-Laurence-Olivier-Awards-Including-Best-Musical "Hairspray Wins Four 2008 Laurence Olivier Awards Including Best Musical"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324015047/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/115735-Hairspray-Wins-Four-2008-Laurence-Olivier-Awards-Including-Best-Musical |date=24 March 2014 }} playbill.com</ref><ref>[http://www.holidayextras.co.uk/news/theatre-breaks/evening-standard-nominations.html "Evening Standard nominations - 2007"] holidayextras.co.uk</ref><ref>[http://westend.broadwayworld.com/article/Critics_Circle_AwardWinners_include_Hairspray_Patrick_Stewart_20080129 ''Broadwayworld.com'']</ref> The show transferred to the [[West End theatre|West End]] on 28 March 2009,<ref>[http://westend.broadwayworld.com/article/WAR_HORSE_Opens_In_The_West_End_32809_20081218 "'War Horse' Opens In The West End 3/28/09"] broadwayworld.com, 8 December 2008</ref> and on 15 March 2011, the show premiered on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Vivian Beaumont Theater]].<ref> {{cite web |url = http://www.playbill.com/news/article/146000-Seth-Numrich-to-Lead-War-Horse-on-Broadway-35-Member-Cast-Announced |title = Seth Numrich to Lead 'War Horse' on Broadway; 35-Member Cast Announced |author = Hetrick, Adam |date = 20 December 2010 |work = |publisher = ''Playbill'' |accessdate = 27 February 2011 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110223210433/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/146000-Seth-Numrich-to-Lead-War-Horse-on-Broadway-35-Member-Cast-Announced |archivedate = 23 February 2011 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>
The company collaborated with [[Neil Bartlett (playwright)|Neil Bartlett]] on ''[[Or You Could Kiss Me]]'', which opened at the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]] in London on 5 October 2010, following previews from 28 September. The show has been described as "an intimate history of two very private lives, lived in extraordinary times."<ref>{{cite web|last=Hetrick|first=Adam|title=Or You Could Kiss Me Opens at London's National Theatre Oct. 5|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/143608-Or-You-Could-Kiss-Me-Opens-at-Londons-National-Theatre-Oct-5|work=Playbill.com|accessdate=4 April 2011|date=5 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020161735/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/143608-Or-You-Could-Kiss-Me-Opens-at-Londons-National-Theatre-Oct-5|archivedate=20 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It closed on 18 November 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Or You Could Kiss Me|url=http://www.nationaltheatre.org.uk/59865/productions/or-you-could-kiss-me.html|work=National Theatre|accessdate=4 April 2011}}</ref>
For the Broadway production of ''[[War Horse (play)|War Horse]]'', the company has received an [[Outer Critics Circle Award|Outer Critics Circle Special Achievement Award]] for "Puppet Design, Fabrication and Direction for ''War Horse''", and they are also a recipient of the 2011 [[Special Tony Award]].<ref name="ga">Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150211-Outer-Critics-Circle-Nominees-Include-Sister-Act-Anything-Goes-Book-of-Mormon "Outer Critics Circle Nominees Include 'Sister Act', 'Anything Goes', 'Book of Mormon' "] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429190413/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/150211-Outer-Critics-Circle-Nominees-Include-Sister-Act-Anything-Goes-Book-of-Mormon |date=29 April 2011 }} playbill.com, 26 April 2011</ref><ref name="Tony">{{cite web| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/tony-awards-2011-book-of-mormon-war-horse-take-top-honors-neil-patrick-harris-impresses-as-host/2011/06/13/AGEEXVTH_story.html |title=Tony Awards 2011: ‘Book of Mormon’, ‘War Horse’ take top honors; Neil Patrick Harris impresses as host |publisher=[[Washington Post]] |last=Marks |first=Peter |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=4 September 2014}}</ref>
== Notes == {{reflist|2}}
== References == *Kentridge, William. "Director's Note". In ''Ubu and the Truth Commission'', by Jane Taylor, viii-xv. Cape Town: University of Cape Town Press, 2007. * Jones, Basil, and Adrian Kohler. "Puppeteers' Note". In ''Ubu and the Truth Commission'', by Jane Taylor, xvi-xvii. Cape Town: University of Cape Town Press, 2007.
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.handspringpuppet.co.za/}}

revision.text:
{{missing information|song structure (changes in time signature) and cultural influence (use of the title as representing gun culture), |date=September 2018}} {{Use British English|date=August 2010}}{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox song | Name = Happiness Is a Warm Gun | Artist = [[the Beatles]] | Album = [[The Beatles (album)|The Beatles]] | Cover = [[File:Happiness Is a Warm Gun sheet music cover.jpg|160px]] | Caption = Cover of the "Happiness Is a Warm Gun" sheet music | Released = 22 November 1968 | track_no = 8 of disc 1 | Recorded = 23–26 September 1968,
[[Abbey Road Studios|EMI Studios]], [[London]] | Genre = [[Hard rock]] | Length = 2:43 | Writer = [[Lennon–McCartney]] | Label = [[Apple Records]] | Producer = [[George Martin]], [[Chris Thomas (record producer)|Chris Thomas]] | Tracks = }} "'''Happiness Is a Warm Gun'''" is a song by [[the Beatles]], featured on the double album ''[[The Beatles (album)|The Beatles]]'' (also known as The White Album), which was released on 22 November 1968. Although credited to [[Lennon–McCartney]], it was written by [[John Lennon]].{{sfn|Spizer|2003|pp=107-108}} ==Writing and inspiration== According to Lennon, the title came from a magazine cover that producer [[George Martin]] showed him: "I think he showed me a cover of a magazine that said 'Happiness Is a Warm Gun.' It was a gun magazine. I just thought it was a fantastic, insane thing to say. A warm gun means you just shot something."{{sfn|Wenner|2000|pp=114–115}} The gun magazine derived the phrase from the bestselling book by ''[[Peanuts]]'' cartoonist [[Charles M. Schulz]], ''Happiness is a Warm Puppy''.{{cite web | date=September 19, 2011 | title=100 Greatest Beatle Songs | publisher=[[Rolling Stone]] | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-beatles-songs-20110919/happiness-is-a-warm-gun-19691231 | access-date=June 2, 2017}} ==Composition== Lennon said he "put together three sections of different songs ... it seemed to run through all the different kinds of rock music..."{{sfn|Wenner|2000|pp=114–115}} and described it as a miniature "history of rock and roll."{{Cite book |title=The Beatles Encyclopedia: Everything Fab Four |last=Womack |first=Kenneth |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2016 |isbn=1440844275 |location=Santa Barbara, CA |pages=179}} This results in a three-part [[through-composed]] structure.{{Cite journal|url = http://www.mtosmt.org/issues/mto.11.17.3/mto.11.17.3.osborn.html|title = Understanding Through-Composition in Post-Rock, Math-Metal, and other Post-Millennial Rock Genres|last = Osborn|first = Brad|date = 2011|journal = Music Theory Online|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |volume = 17| issue = 3}} The song begins with surreal imagery allegedly taken from an [[LSD|acid]] trip that Lennon and [[Derek Taylor]] experienced, with Taylor contributing the opening lines.{{sfn|Hertsgaard|1995|p=257}} The three sections of the song were described by Lennon as "the dirty old man...the junkie...and the gunman."{{Cite book |title=The Beatles Encyclopedia: Everything Fab Four |last=Womack |first=Kenneth |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2016 |isbn=1440844275 |location=Santa Barbara, CA |pages=179}} ==In the studio== "Happiness Is a Warm Gun" reportedly is [[Paul McCartney]]'s and was [[George Harrison]]'s favourite song on the White Album.{{sfn|Spizer|2003|p=108}} Although tensions were high among the band during the album's recording sessions, they reportedly collaborated as a close unit to work out the song's challenging rhythmic and metre issues.{{sfn|Inglis|2000}} Recording of the song began at 7 pm in Studio Two at [[Abbey Road Studios|EMI Studios]] in London on 23 September 1968, continued over the following two nights, with daytime breaks, and was completed at 5 am on 26 September.{{sfn|Lewisohn|1995|p=300}} [[Piano]], [[electronic organ]] and [[tuba]] parts in this recording are unattributed; the tuba was all but removed through mixing.{{harvnb|Lewisohn|1995|p=300}}; {{harvnb|Lewis|Spignesi|2004|p=86}}. George Martin was on holiday while this song was recorded, and had left a note asking [[Chris Thomas (record producer)|Chris Thomas]] to take over as producer.{{sfn|Lewisohn|1995|pp=298–301}} ==Personnel== According to [[Ian MacDonald]]:{{sfn|MacDonald|1998|p=279}} *[[John Lennon]] – [[doubletracking|double-tracked]] lead vocal, electric guitar, backing vocal *[[Paul McCartney]] – bass guitar, backing vocal *[[George Harrison]] – lead guitar, backing vocal *[[Ringo Starr]] – drums, tambourine ==Interpretations== Many different interpretations of the song have been offered. Some writers have suggested that the "warm gun" could refer to Lennon's sexual desire for [[Yoko Ono]].{{sfn|Marck|2009}} In his 1980 ''[[Playboy]]'' interview Lennon admitted to the double meaning of guns and sexuality but denied that the song had anything to do with drugs: "that was the beginning of my relationship with Yoko and I was very sexually oriented then."{{sfn|Sheff|2000|p=188}} American and British censors were unhappy with the song, and it was banned by the [[BBC]].{{sfn|Dowlding|1989|p=230}} ==Cover versions== * [[Tori Amos]], on the album ''[[Strange Little Girls]]''.{{cite web|title=Strange Little Girls - Tori Amos|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/strange-little-girls-mw0000011921|publisher=AllMusic|accessdate=7 September 2017}} * [[Phish]], on the album ''[[Live Phish Volume 13]]''.{{cite web|title=Live Phish, Vol. 13: 10/31/94, Glens Falls Civic Center, Glens Falls, NY - Phish|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/live-phish-vol-13-10-31-94-glens-falls-civic-center-glens-falls-ny-mw0000226969|publisher=AllMusic|accessdate=7 September 2017}} * [[U2]], as a B-side of the single "[[Last Night on Earth (U2 song)|Last Night on Earth]]." * [[Joe Anderson (actor)|Joe Anderson]] with [[Salma Hayek]], for the soundtrack of ''[[Across the Universe (film)|Across the Universe]]''{{sfn|IMDb|2009}} * [[The Breeders]], on the album ''[[Pod (The Breeders album)|Pod]]'' * [[Marc Ribot]], on the album ''[[Saints (Marc Ribot album)|Saints]]'' ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * {{Cite book | first=William J. | last=Dowlding | title=Beatlesongs | year=1989 | publisher=Simon & Schuster Inc | isbn=0-671-68229-6 | ref=harv }} * {{Cite book | last=Hertsgaard | first=Mark | year=1995 | title=A Day in the Life: The Music and Artistry of The Beatles | publisher=[[Delacorte Press]] | location=New York | isbn=0-385-31377-2 | ref=harv }} * {{cite web | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0445922/soundtrack | title=''Across the Universe'' soundtrack | publisher=[[Internet Movie Database|IMDb]] | accessdate=24 September 2009 | ref={{SfnRef|IMDb|2009}} }} * {{Cite book | last=Inglis | first=Ian | title=The Beatles, Popular Music and Society: A Thousand Voices | publisher=Palgrave Macmillan Publishing | year=2000 | ref=harv }} *{{Cite book | last1=Lewis | first1=Michael | last2=Spignesi | first2=Stephen J. | title=100 Best Beatles Songs: A Passionate Fan's Guide | publisher=Black Dog & Leventhal | year=2004 | isbn= 978-1-60376-265-6 | ref=harv }} *{{Cite book | last=Lewisohn | first=Mark | title=The Complete Beatles Chronicle | publisher=Hamlyn | year=1995 | isbn=0-600-58749-5 | ref=harv }} * {{cite book|last=MacDonald| first=Ian| year=1998| title=Revolution in the Head: The Beatles' Records and the Sixties| publisher=Pimlico|location=London| isbn=978-0-7126-6697-8| ref=harv}} * {{cite web | last=Marck | first=John T. | year=2009 | work=I Am The Beatles | url=http://www.iamthebeatles.com/article1163.html | title=Happiness Is a Warm Gun | ref=harv }} * {{Cite book | last=Sheff | first=David | year=2000 | title=All We Are Saying | publisher=St Martin's Griffin | isbn=0-312-25464-4 | ref=harv }} * {{Cite book | last=Spizer | first=Bruce | year=2003 | title=The Beatles on Apple Records | publisher=498 Productions | isbn=0-9662649-4-0 | ref=harv }} * {{Cite book | last=Wenner | first=Jann S | year=2000 | authorlink=Jann Wenner | title=Lennon Remembers (Full interview from Lennon's 1970 interview in [[Rolling Stone]] magazine) | publisher=Verso | location=London | isbn=1-85984-600-9 | ref=harv }} ==External links== {{Wikiquote|The Beatles (album)}} {{The Beatles (White Album)}} [[Category:1968 songs]] [[Category:The Beatles songs]] [[Category:Music medleys]] [[Category:Songs about happiness]] [[Category:Songs about sexuality]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Chris Thomas (record producer)]] [[Category:Songs published by Northern Songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Lennon–McCartney]] [[Category:Censorship of music]] [[Category:Obscenity controversies in music]]

{{for|the song by Airbourne|Runnin' Wild (Airbourne album)}} {{for|the song by Mango Groove|Hellfire (Mango Groove song)}} {{Infobox song | Name = Hellfire | Cover = | Artist = [[Tony Jay]] | Album = [[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (soundtrack)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame: An Original Walt Disney Records Soundtrack]] | track_no = 7 | Released = 1996 | Recorded = 1996 | Genre = [[Musical theatre]] | Length = 5:22 (including "[[Heaven's Light]]") | Label = [[Walt Disney Records|Walt Disney]] | Writer = {{flat list| *[[Alan Menken]] *[[Stephen Schwartz (composer)|Stephen Schwartz]] }} | Producer = {{flat list| *[[Alan Menken]] *[[Stephen Schwartz (composer)|Stephen Schwartz]] }} | prev = "The Bell Tower" | prev_no = 6 | next = "[[A Guy Like You]]" | next_no = 8 }}
"'''Hellfire'''" is a song from [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Disney's]] [[1996 in film|1996]] [[animated feature]] ''[[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996 film)|The Hunchback of Notre Dame]]''. The song is sung by the film's main [[antagonist]], [[Judge Claude Frollo]], who is voiced by [[Tony Jay]].
When sinful thoughts regarding the beautiful [[Romani people|Romani]] woman [[Esmeralda (The Hunchback of Notre Dame)|Esmeralda]] enter Frollo's mind, he "panics and seeks to rid himself of [its] source". This internal struggle prompts "Hellfire", which has been described as "one of the best Disney villain songs of all time".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://blogcritics.org/video/article/movie-review-the-hunchback-of-notre/ | title=Movie Review: The Hunchback of Notre Dame (1996) | accessdate=January 8, 2013}}</ref> Frollo "confronts his [[lust]]ing for Esmeralda, blaming her for turning towards darkness, and pleading to be saved". He sings "destroy Esmeralda, and let her taste the fires of hell, or else let her be mine and mine alone" while the image of Esmeralda "provocatively dances in front of him".<ref name="denofgeek">{{cite web | first=Simon|last=Brew|url=http://www.denofgeek.com/movies/17457/looking-back-at-disney%E2%80%99s-the-hunchback-of-notre-dame | title=Looking back at Disney's The Hunchback Of Notre Dame | website=[[Den of Geek]]| publisher=[[Dennis Publishing]]| location=New York City| date=May 16, 2011 | accessdate=January 8, 2013 }}</ref>
This "scene of lust and longing" that the song is centered on received much press coverage at the time of the film's release, along with the alterations made to give the film a [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|"G" rating]].
=="Heaven's Light" and "Hellfire"== The song was intended to contrast with the song "[[Heaven's Light]]", which was sung by [[Quasimodo]] moments earlier, expressing his desire for love and hope that Esmeralda may love him, while "Hellfire" focuses on Frollo's [[internal conflict]] between his feelings of lust for her and his piety and hatred of the Gypsies.
Both songs, which are sometimes referred to collectively as "Heaven's Light"/"Hellfire" (for example on [[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (soundtrack)|the soundtrack]], in which it is track 7), describe two opposing views towards the same woman. Quasimodo sees love as "Heaven's Light" and expresses a pure hope for Esmeralda, while Frollo feels only lust for her and therefore views her as a "Hellfire".<ref name="Griffin, Sean 217–8">{{cite book |first=Sean| last=Griffin|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=id1MiOWqirgC&pg=PA217&dq=%22the+hunchback+of+notre+dame%22+hellfire&hl=en&sa=X&ei=9uvrUPnWJeWtiQfd2oCoBw&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22the%20hunchback%20of%20notre%20dame%22%20hellfire&f=false | title=Tinker Belles and Evil Queens: The Walt Disney Company from the Inside Out | date=February 1, 2000 | accessdate=January 8, 2013 |publisher=[[New York University Press|NYU Press]] | location=New York City| pages=217–8 | isbn= 0814731236}}</ref>
Simon Brew of ''[[Den of Geek!]]'' argues that throughout the song Frollo goes through a similar kind of torture that Quasimodo puts himself through in "Heaven's Light".<ref name="denofgeek" />
=== Other languages === Underlining the strong link between the two songs, the [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] version enclosed them in one track, giving only one title: "Himmel og Helvete" meaning ==Composition== {{Listen|type=music|pos=right|filename=Hellfire from Hunchback of Notre Dame.ogg|title=Hellfire|description=This 30 second excerpt of "Hellfire" illustrates Frollo's internal struggle. The clip includes the final part of verse 1 and the beginning of chorus 1.}}
It begins in [[Bb major|B flat major]], before turning to its [[relative minor]] [[G minor|G]]. It soon modulates briefly into [[C minor]], then [[F major]], has a spoken intersection where the bass lies on A, [[Dominant (music)|dominant]] of [[D minor]], the key in which the song finally ends.
"Hellfire" contains parts of the [[Confiteor]], a [[Latin language|Latin]] prayer of confession used by the [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic Church]]. This prayer begins directly after "Heaven's Light" and serves as the introduction to "Hellfire". It also provides counterpoint material throughout the song, whose ending also contains the "[[Kyrie|Kyrie Eleison]]".
The instrumental accompaniment to the song serves as a musical motif that alters in tone depending on the action. As well as some variations heard early on (such as in "[[The Bells of Notre Dame]]"), this motif "informs much of the score that chronologically follows in the film." Reviewer Christian Clemmensen of [[Filmtracks.com]] adds that "both 'Paris Burning' and 'Sanctuary!' explicitly continue the instrumental backdrop and Latin chanting of 'Hellfire', a sound that becomes more general in 'And He Shall Smite the Wicked'."<ref name="filmtracks">{{cite web|url=http://www.filmtracks.com/titles/hunchback.html |title=The Hunchback of Notre Dame (Alan Menken) |publisher=Filmtracks |date= |accessdate=2012-02-21}}</ref> Also, "the opening fanfare is also reintroduced at the end of 'Heaven's Light', makes up the melody during the chorus of 'Hellfire', and plays in the instrumental 'Sanctuary!'"
==Visual sequence== [[Image:Frollohellfire.PNG|Frollo's lustful vision of Esmeralda from his fireplace.|thumb]] The beginning of the song starts with the Archdeacon swinging the incense-filled [[thurible]], as he and his altar servers walk through [[Notre Dame de Paris|Notre Dame]], chanting the beginning of the [[Confiteor]]. The camera pans upwards to the famous [[rose window]], and flies through it and over Paris, revealing that all the lights in the city are going out as people are turning in for the night. The only light that remains is the light in the [[Palais de Justice, Paris|Palace of Justice]] where Frollo looks out at Notre Dame from his window, singing to the [[Virgin Mary]] (whom he addresses as "Beata Maria", in [[Latin language|Latin]]) about how she knows he is "a righteous man" and purer than "the common, vulgar, weak, licentious crowd". Frollo walks to the fireplace and fearfully asks Mary to tell him why he lusts for Esmeralda if he is pure. During this, a fire apparition of Esmeralda dances provocatively in the flames.
During the second verse, Frollo steps back from the fireplace, revealing a piece of silk that Esmeralda had used to tease him earlier in the film. Frollo sings about how he lusts for her and resents her for it. He accuses her of turning him to [[sin]] and denies his own culpability as red-hooded figures rise from the floor, chanting "''[[mea culpa]]''" ("my fault"). Frollo runs through the chamber, with the cloaked figures standing on either side of him. He desperately pleads with them for forgiveness, claiming that Esmeralda had cast a spell on him and tempted him. He asks if it is in a part of God's plan that God made [[the Devil]] stronger than "a man," though in reality this refers to (Frollo) himself. The hooded figures turn into flames, wrapping Frollo as they return to the fireplace as if he was being dragged down into [[Hell]], thereby foreshadowing his fate.
Frollo continues singing, pleading to Mary to rescue him from Esmeralda's voluptuous temptations that would lead to his eternal [[damnation]]. He holds out the scarf and clenches it angrily, stating that Esmeralda must choose him or burn. The fire apparition of Esmeralda reappears, but her provocative dancing is replaced by her shriek-filled writhing as she is about to burn. A smoke apparition of Esmeralda emerges from the fireplace (pictured above), and as it and Frollo embrace passionately, there is a knock at the door. The apparition disappears as a guard enters, informing Frollo that Esmeralda escaped from the Cathedral of Notre Dame where Frollo had "imprisoned" her. Frollo vows to find her, even if it involves burning down all of Paris. The guard then leaves, and Frollo continues singing, claiming that he will give Esmeralda an ultimatum: she must choose to be his lover or she will burn. Frollo then throws Esmeralda's scarf into the fireplace, symbolically burning her as well.
In the final verse, Frollo backs up against a wall, and asks God to have mercy on both him and Esmeralda, implying that he ultimately knows that his actions are against God's will. As he sings, shadowy figures holding crucifixes emerge from the light of the fireplace and fly past Frollo, who then drops to his knees, saying that Esmeralda will be his lover or she will burn. Finishing the song, Frollo passes out and falls face down on the floor in the shape of a crucifix as the fire fades.
==Production== The producers of Disney's adaptation of ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' stated that they felt that the "Hellfire" scene was important in portraying Frollo as he was in [[Victor Hugo]]'s [[The Hunchback of Notre Dame|original novel]]. They hoped that this sequence would be one of the greatest animated sequences ever produced. Frollo was animated by Kathy Zielinski and the sequence was [[storyboard]]ed by French animators [[Paul and Gaëtan Brizzi]], who were the heads of the [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Feature Animation]] satellite studio in [[Montreuil, Seine-Saint-Denis|Montreuil]], [[France]].<ref name="ParisStudio">{{cite news|last=Swarden|first=Anne|date=1997-01-01 |title=Parisian Moviegoers Flock To See Hunchback |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1957&dat=19970101&id=tFhGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wugMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5979,121705 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |accessdate=2014-06-22 }}</ref> The elements of fire, smoke, and shadows in the sequence required significant support from the Feature Animation visual effects department.<ref name=audiocommentary /> According to one of the film's directors, [[Kirk Wise]], Frollo's song "Hellfire" needed a visual sequence more meaningful and powerful than past Disney animated features, akin to the ''Night on Bald Mountain'' sequence in Disney's ''[[Fantasia (1940 film)|Fantasia]]'' (1940), which depicted the devil [[Chernabog]] rallying his demons for a single night.
In the audio commentary on ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' DVD, Wise described his fear that he would have to plead with Feature Animation chairman [[Roy E. Disney]] and Walt Disney Company CEO [[Michael Eisner]] to let them do the sequence. The two executives ended up enjoying the idea, and no plea was needed.<ref name=audiocommentary>Trousdale, Gary; Wise, Kirk; and Hahn, Don (2006). DVD audio commentary for ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame''. Walt Disney Home Entertainment</ref>
Wise also indicated that he and visual effects artistic supervisor [[Chris Jenkins (film producer)|Chris Jenkins]] wanted to make sure the "fire-spirit" shots of Esmeralda in the sequence would not endanger the film's possibilities of earning a [[Motion Picture Association of America film rating system|"G" rating]] from the [[Motion Picture Association of America]]. Thus, they went through every frame to ensure that Esmeralda's figure was fully clothed at all times,<ref name=audiocommentary/> despite her provocative dancing.
==Themes== The Latin Chant in the background is the Confiteor, which is a Catholic penitential prayer recited during [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]] as an "admission of guilt and wrongdoing". There is a sense of dramatic irony throughout the song as Frollo sings "It's not my fault / I'm not to blame / It is the gypsy girl / The witch who sent this flame / It's not my fault / If in God's plan / He made the devil so much / Stronger than a man", to which the priests (at this point of the song represented by ominous red-hooded figures) reply in a counterpoint melody with "''Mea culpa''", Latin for "My fault", or "''Mea maxima culpa''", meaning "My most grievous fault"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fpx.de/fp/Disney/Lyrics/Hunchback.html|title=Song Lyrics: Hunchback of Notre Dame|website=Fpx.de|accessdate=22 June 2018}}</ref>.
An analysis at "Disney and the Seven Deadly Sins" suggests that the Confiteor chant "manifest[s] as his conscience", and reveals to Frollo "the truth of his actions in regard to lust," which is "a craving for sexual intimacy," leading him to self-indulgence. This "desire for the flesh of another" is a sin, which Frollo struggles over until the very end of his life. Even "when Frollo prepares to burn Esmeralda at the stake in front of the cathedral he offers Esmeralda a chance to live if she agrees to be his lover." The article "''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'': The House of the Lord" in ''The Gospel According to Disney'' suggests that "Frollo is tortured by his lust for Esmeralda, an unrequited passion that curdles into obsessive hatred", and argues that Frollo "prays to be delivered from his sin, prostrating himself before a roaring fire, with a cross above it," and while being presented with two paths, he ultimately chooses lust which leads to his downfall. This sin of the villain is compared to [[Jafar (Aladdin)|Jafar]]'s greed for power at the end of ''[[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|Aladdin]]''. When Frollo is about to kill Quasimodo and Esmeralda, he quotes a biblical verse (supporting the notion that he justifies his wrongdoings as God's will): "And [[God|He]] shall smite the [[Witch|wicked]] and plunge them into the [[Hell|fiery pit]]!" ''The Gospel According to Disney'' describes what happens next as follows, "Just then, the judge falls to his own death [a pit of fire], in an act of divine intervention."<ref name="disneyandsin.weebly">{{cite web | url=http://disneyandsin.weebly.com/lust.html | title=Disney and the Seven Deadly Sins|website=Sisneyandsin.weebly.com | accessdate=January 8, 2013}}</ref>
Jim Miles of Laughingplace.com analyses "Hellfire" by saying that the song marks the turning point when "Frollo's hate for the gypsies has taken on a new dimension", and is "no longer about ending vice and sin [but] about fulfilling his own desires". The scarf he takes from Esmeralda "symboli[zes] the physical manifestation of his desire for [her]", and the resulting internal struggle is illustrated in the song. His life's work involves making the city of Paris "pure and righteous", and no matter how much he wants to be too, he sees a "flame...burning within him" and so turns to God (represented by Mary in the song, notable that in his lust he prays to the Holy Virgin) to "help him overcome those feelings". However throughout his pleading, he holds onto the scarf, thereby holding onto the sin. He tries to rationalize the sin before the "judges of his heart", and seems to be returned to purity, but after the judges disappear the temptation returns. Though he sings "Protect me, Maria" with "repentant agony on his face", he stares into the fireplace and holds onto the scarf, giving into temptation. After being "interrupted by the soldier, he makes a decision within his heart to hold on to the sin". Because the "desire [is now] firmly rooted [within him], he is able to throw away the scarf - the external representation of his inner feelings - into the fire as he has fully accepted this persona. After doing this, he "realizes his mistake, and visually, we see the spiritual battle for his soul--crosses rising above shadowy spiritual figures--but even then, he reconfirms his resolution and proclaims that "she will be mine or she will burn."<ref name="laughingplace">{{cite web | url=http://www.laughingplace.com/news-id180330.asp | title=101 Reasons: The Hunchback of Notre Dame | accessdate=January 8, 2013}}</ref>
Sean Griffin in his work ''Tinker Belles and Evil Queens: The Walt Disney Company from the Inside Out'' says that Frollo's hate for Esmeralda seems to stem from his hatred of his own feelings. His shame of "turning to sin" overwhelms him, and he turns to blaming and punishing others. He says that although Frollo's lust for Esmeralda is strictly heterosexual, his behaviour "mirrors conclusions from studies about homophobia...unconscious conflicts about one's own sexuality or gender identity." He argues that "Frollo's grim determinations to punish Esmeralda [throughout 'Hellfire']" are sparked from his own denial that he has "'urges' that fall outside the rigid parameters of social acceptance."<ref name="Griffin, Sean 217–8"/>
Miles argues that the "Archdeacon acts as a foil for Frollo" because through his "caring for Quasimodo's dead mother, he exhibits the kindness and love that God calls all Christians to, which is what Frollo fails to understand". He shows Esmeralda compassion while Frollo only feels contempt towards her. He also "does what Frollo should have done" by "direct[ing] her attention to God." The climax of this is when "he leads a prayer in Latin that calls upon God, Mary, the archangel Michael, the apostles, the saints, and...the Father, for forgiveness of sin in thought, word, and deed." This leads straight into "Hellfire". Miles says that "while the Archdeacon turns from sin, Frollo chooses to toy with sin."<ref name="laughingplace" />
There is a juxtaposition of imagery between [[Heaven]] and [[Hell]] between the two parts of "Heaven's Lights"/"Hellfire".
==Home media release== The [[LaserDisc]] provided the [[song demo]] for "Hellfire", as well as for "The Bells of Notre Dame" and "[[Out There (song)|Out There]]".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dvdizzy.com/hunchback.htm | title=Review | website=DVDizzy.com | accessdate=January 8, 2013}}</ref>
==Critical reception== The song was universally acclaimed, and it is considered to be one of the highlights of the [[The Hunchback of Notre Dame (soundtrack)|soundtrack to ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'']] which in turn received mixed reviews. The general consensus is that if the direction taken with "Hellfire" had been taken for the other songs, the film as a whole would have been substantially better.
In a review of the film's soundtrack, Christian Clemmensen of [[Filmtracks.com]] stated that "the darkest depths of ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' exist in 'Hellfire', one of the most stunning visual and aural combinations in animation history." Though the film was aimed at children as well as adults, Clemmensen comments that the "constantly frightening Latin chants and a heavy string, timpani, and choral bass" scared the younger demographic (despite attempts at lighthearted music and humour to dilute the film). He argues that if Disney had fully embraced the dark nature of the source material by building the soundtrack upon numbers like "Hellfire" and "Sanctuary!", "the film could have been a brilliant adult feature." He says the "spattering of comedy pieces", which include three "silly songs", are "a significant detriment to the gains of the aforementioned themes and performances", and ultimately cause both the film and soundtrack to be a "mixed bag." Pieces such as "Hellfire" are "serious, dramatically brilliant [and among] some of Menken's very best work."<ref name="filmtracks" /> Later on in his review, Clemmensen notes the Latin mass which leads into "[Tony] Jay's hauntingly deep performance of Frollo's torment," and adds that it "produc[es] a song so overwhelmingly compelling in an evil sense that it alone was worth the cost of admission (and the album)."<ref name="filmtracks" />
Jim Miles of Laughingplace.com says that "Frollo's passionate pleading" is "visually astounding, masterfully conceived and animated," and the "standout" of the film. He adds that "accompanied by intense music of agony and complex lyrics of psychological revelation, 'Hellfire' is everything a musical scene aspires to be."<ref name="laughingplace" /> Reviewer Kenneth E. Rathburn said the song's "grandeur... contributes and fulfills" more than other songs, such as "[[A Guy Like You]]", making it one of the better tracks.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sputnikmusic.com/review/52185/Disney-Soundtracks-The-Hunchback-of-Notre-Dame/ | title=Disney Soundtracks The Hunchback of Notre Dame | date=September 29, 2012 | accessdate=January 8, 2013 | author=Rathburn, Kenneth E.}}</ref> Jack Smith of the [[BBC]] describes the tone (set by the opening number) as "an unholy marriage of the Tridentine Mass and Les Mis." He says the score, "driven by hysterical choirs and crashing percussion" is most effective in "Hellfire".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/fd54 | title=Alan Menken The Hunchback of Notre Dame Review | date=2004-08-10 | accessdate=January 8, 2013 | author=Smith, Jack}}</ref> The ''[[San Antonio Express-News]]'' described it as ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame''{{'}}s "true show-stopping tune."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SAEC&p_theme=saec&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB03D7CAECF7FF2&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | title='Hunchback' entertains, yet keeps its message | accessdate=January 8, 2013 | first=Larry | last=Ratliff}}</ref> Simon Brew of ''Den of Geek!'' says the suffering Frollo goes through in this song makes him a "far more rounded villain." He describes "Hellfire" as "a stunning piece of work, with the visuals and music working in complete tandem."<ref name="denofgeek" />
Internet comedian [[Doug Walker (actor)|Doug Walker]], a fan of the movie, named it the No. 1 villain song on his list of the top 11 villain songs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://channelawesome.com/nostalgia-critic-top-11-villain-songs/|title=Top 11 Villain Songs|website=Channelawesome.com|accessdate=22 June 2018}}</ref>
==Controversy== The song is considered to be one of the darkest in any Disney film, depicting [[Hell]], [[sin]], [[damnation]], and [[lust]]; examples of subject matter that would generally be considered [[inappropriate for children]]. This song and visual sequence prompted the ratings board to consider a PG rating for the film. In its defense, Disney claimed that its adaptation of ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' was intended to play as much to adult audiences as it would to children. The studio attempted to produce an animated film with an audience broader than only children: the main target audience of Disney animated features.
In ''Film Genre 2000: New Critical Essays'', film critic Marc Miller said that "Hellfire" "was too much for many adults," which prompted reviewers such as Mark Silver of ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' to say things like: "[''Hunchback'' is] a beautiful powerful film that I would not recommend to children under eight or nine years old."<ref>{{cite book |first=Marc|last=Miller|editor-first=Wheeler W.|editor-last=Dixon|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dgzACTHIAcsC&pg=PA54&dq=%22the+hunchback+of+notre+dame%22+hellfire&hl=en&sa=X&ei=J_brUJ6PKIznkgX394A4&ved=0CDsQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=%22the%20hunchback%20of%20notre%20dame%22%20hellfire&f=false | title=Film Genre 2000: New Critical Essays | chapter=Of Tunes and Toons|publisher=[[SUNY Press]]|location=Albany, New York|date=2000| page=54| ISBN=978-0791445143|accessdate=January 8, 2013 }}</ref>
Animator Floyd Norman recalled the pitching session for the musical, in which Menken and Schwartz were "on hand to perform the songs that would grace the production." He recalls "Hellfire" "clearly ha[ving] the executives squirming nervously," wondering if this material could be in a Disney film.<ref>{{cite book | first=Floyd|last=Norman|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PMK9MQLnRCEC&pg=PT109&dq=%22the+hunchback+of+notre+dame%22+hellfire&hl=en&sa=X&ei=J_brUJ6PKIznkgX394A4&ved=0CEEQ6AEwAjgK | title=Animated Life: A Lifetime of tips, tricks, techniques and stories from a Disney Legend | chapter=Monster in the Bell Tower|page=109|publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]]|location=Abingdon, England|date=2013|accessdate=January 8, 2013|ISBN=978-1136126376 }}</ref>
The "Hellfire" subplot, "involving the villain’s need to desire to screw and/or murder the heroine because of his guilt-ridden lustings for her," which was described as "a cross between ''[[Schindler’s List]]'' and ''[[Sweeney Todd (musical)|Sweeney Todd]]''" by Scott Mendelson of HollywoodNews.com, was also referred to by him as one of the Disney events such as [[Mufasa]] being killed onscreen in ''The Lion King'', that surprisingly were given "G-ratings from the [[MPAA]] back in the 1990s," which Mendelson uses as context when discussing ''[[Tangled]]''{{'}}s PG rating.<ref>{{cite web |first=Scott|last=Mendelson|url=http://www.hollywoodnews.com/2010/10/18/cartoon-movies-are-having-a-hard-time-getting-g-ratings-these-days/ | title=Cartoon movies are having a hard time getting "G" ratings these days | website=HollywoodNews.com|date=October 18, 2010|accessdate=January 8, 2013 }}</ref>
Religious conservatives boycotted ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' due to this song, which they said was "a suggestive rejection of purity amplified by imagery of a half-naked Esmeralda dancing in a fire."<ref name="filmtracks" />

[[File:Eurosonic Noorderslag 2011 - 22tracks winnaar The Interactive Company Award 2011 - by Jack Tillmanns.jpg|thumb|right|250px|22tracks wins The Interactive Company Award 2011 - by Jack Tillmanns - Foto Focus]] The '''Interactive Awards''' are awarded to artists, bands and music organizations that use the internet in an inventive way to market (their) music. Since 2008 the Interactive Awards are presented on an annual basis during The European Music Conference and Showcase Festival [[Eurosonic Noorderslag]] in the Dutch city of [[Groningen (city)| Groningen]].<ref>{{nl}}[http://www.bumastemra.nl/en-US/OverBumaStemra/Actueel/Winners+Interactive+Awards.html, "Eurosonic Noorderslag - Palomine and 22tracks winners Interactive Awards 2011"], ''Bumastemra.nl'', 1 oktober 2010</ref> The award aims to encourage European talent and highlight artists and bands that inspire others in an interactive field.<ref name = "Interactive Award" /> Two awards are presented at the Interactive Awards, namely the Company Award and the Artist Award. <ref name = "Interactive Award" />The Artist Award aims to highlight artists or bands with special online initiatives. The prize includes a gift of 5000 euro’s. <ref name = "Interactive Award">[http://www.interactive-award.nl/index.cfm, "Interactive Award"], ''Interactive-award.nl''. Retrieved August 24, 2011</ref> The Company Award was introduced to support online (music) portals and was added to the Interactive Awards in 2010. <ref>{{nl}}[http://www.livexs.nl/2009/nieuws/11116/ook-interactive-company-award-tijdens-eurosonic-noorderslag-2010/, "Ook Interactive Company Awards tijdens Eurosonic Noorderslag 2010"]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''Livexs.nl'', 8 november 2009</ref> The Interactive Awards are an initiative of internet agency theFactor.e and Dutch Music rights Foundation [[Buma/Stemra]].<ref name = "Interactive Award" /> The Interactive Awards are hosted by Eurosonic Noorderslag.
==Winners== '''2011''' *Artist Award: [[Palomine]] *Company Award: [[:nl:22tracks|22tracks]] '''2010''' *Artist Award: [[Krause]] *Company Award: [[Sellaband]] '''2009''' * Artist Award: [[Silence is Sexy]] '''2008''' *Artist Award: [[:nl:VanKatoen|VanKatoen]]
